{{History of Croatia}}
[[File:FranjoTudman.JPG|thumbnail|[[Franjo Tuđman]], 1st democratically elected and 1st president of modern independent [[Republic of Croatia]]]] The '''independence of [[Croatia]]''' was a process started with the changes in the political system and the constitutional changes in 1990 that transformed the [[Socialist Republic of Croatia]] into the [[Republic of Croatia]], which in turn proclaimed the [[Christmas Constitution]], and held the [[Croatian independence referendum, 1991]].
After the country formally declared independence in June 1991, and the dissolution of its association with [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]], it introduced a [[Brioni Agreement|three-month moratorium on the decision]] when urged to do so by the [[European Community]] and the [[Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe]]. During that time the [[Croatian War of Independence]] started.
On 8 October 1991, the [[Croatian Parliament]] severed all remaining ties with Yugoslavia. The [[Badinter Arbitration Committee]] had to rule on the matter. Finally, the Croatian independence was internationally recognized in January 1992, when both the [[European Economic Community]] and the [[United Nations]] granted Croatia [[diplomatic recognition]], and the country was accepted into the United Nations shortly thereafter.
==Background== [[File:Hrvatski sabor (2).jpg|left|thumb|[[Croatian Parliament]] building]] During the [[World War II]] period from 1941 to 1945, Croatia was established as a [[puppet state]] called the [[Independent State of Croatia]], governed by the [[ultranationalism|ultranationalist]], [[fascism|fascist]] [[Ustaše]], backed by [[Nazi Germany]] and [[Kingdom of Italy#Fascist regime (1922–1943)|Fascist Italy]] within the territory of the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]. From 1945 it became a [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|Socialist federal unit]] of the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], a [[one-party state]] run by the [[League of Communists of Croatia]] created at the end of [[World War II in Yugoslavia]]. Croatia enjoyed a degree of autonomy within the Yugoslav federation. At the turn of the 1970s, a Croatian national protest movement called the [[Croatian Spring]] was suppressed by Yugoslav leadership.<ref name="JL-Savka">{{cite news |newspaper=[[Jutarnji list]] |language=Croatian |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/heroina-hrvatskog-proljeca/305499/ |title=Heroina Hrvatskog proljeća |trans-title=Heroine of the Croatian Spring |date=6 August 2009 |author=Vlado Vurušić |accessdate=14 October 2011 |archivedate=25 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QmExEdP?url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/heroina-hrvatskog-proljeca/305499/ |df= }}</ref> Still, the [[1974 Yugoslav Constitution]] gave increased autonomy to federal units, essentially fulfilling a goal of the Croatian Spring and providing a legal basis for independence of the federative constituents.<ref name="Rich">{{cite journal |first=Roland |last=Rich |title=Recognition of States: The Collapse of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union |journal=European Journal of International Law |year=1993 |issue=1 |volume=4 |pages=36–65 |url=http://www.ejil.org/article.php?article=1207&issue=67 |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref>
In the 1980s, the political situation in Yugoslavia deteriorated, with national tension fanned by the 1986 Serbian [[Memorandum of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts|SANU Memorandum]] and the [[Anti-bureaucratic revolution|1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo and Montenegro]].<ref name="frucht433">Frucht 2005, p. 433</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Reuters]] |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE7D9123FF931A25752C0A96F948260&scp=2&sq=Titograd&st=nyt |title=Leaders of a Republic In Yugoslavia Resign |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=12 January 1989 |accessdate=7 February 2010 |archivedate=25 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QmSYE7N?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world/leaders-of-a-republic-in-yugoslavia-resign.html |df= }}</ref> As Slovenia and Croatia began to seek greater autonomy within the federation, including [[confederation|confederate]] status and even full independence, the nationalist ideas started to grow within the ranks of the still-ruling League of Communists. As [[Slobodan Milošević]] rose to power in Serbia, his speeches favored continuation of a unified Yugoslav state—one in which all power would be centralized in [[Belgrade]].<ref name="Annex IV">{{cite web|title=Final report of the United Nations Commission of Experts established pursuant to security council resolution 780 (1992), Annex IV – The policy of ethnic cleansing; Prepared by: M. Cherif Bassiouni. |publisher=United Nations |date=December 28, 1994 |url=http://www.ess.uwe.ac.uk/comexpert/anx/IV.htm |accessdate=March 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504142243/http://www.ess.uwe.ac.uk/comexpert/ANX/IV.htm |archivedate=May 4, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Brown116">[[#Brown & Karim|Brown & Karim (1995)]], p. 116</ref> In March 1989, the crisis in Yugoslavia deepened after the adoption of amendments to the Serbian constitution that allowed the Serbian republic's government to re-assert effective power over the autonomous provinces of Kosovo and Vojvodina. Up until that time, a number of political decisions were legislated from within these provinces, and they had a vote on the [[List of heads of state of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav federal presidency]] level (six members from the republics and two members from the autonomous provinces).<ref>{{cite web|title=A Country Study: Yugoslavia (Former): Political Innovation and the 1974 Constitution (chapter 4) | url= http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/yutoc.html#yu0130 | publisher= The Library of Congress| accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref> In the [[Gazimestan speech]], delivered on June 28, 1989, Milošević remarked on the current "battles and quarrels", saying that even though there were currently no armed battles, the possibility could not be excluded yet.<ref name="Guardian-Gazimestan">{{cite news | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/jul/01/balkans.warcrimes | title = Tyrant's defeat marks Serbs' day of destiny | author= Tim Judah | authorlink= Tim Judah | date= July 1, 2001 | accessdate=December 19, 2010}}</ref> The general political situation grew more tense when in 1989 [[Vojislav Šešelj]] publicly consorted with [[Momčilo Đujić]], a World War II [[Chetniks|Chetnik]] leader.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.icty.org/x/cases/seselj/ind/en/ses-ii030115e.pdf | format = PDF | title = Vojislav Seselj indictment | date = January 15, 2003 | publisher = The [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] | accessdate =October 8, 2010}}</ref> Years later, Croatian Serb leader [[Milan Babić]] testified that Momčilo Đujić had financially supported the Serbs in Croatia in the 1990s.<ref name="ICTY-Milosevic-Transcript">{{cite web | url= http://www.icty.org/x/cases/slobodan_milosevic/trans/en/021204IT.htm | title= Slobodan Milosevic Transcript, case NO. IT-94-1-T | date= December 4, 2002 | accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref> Conversely, [[Franjo Tuđman]] made international visits during the late 1980s to garner support from the [[Croatian diaspora]] for the Croatian national cause.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/tudmana-je-posjeta-americi-1987-trebao-ubiti-srpski-vojni-likvidator-clanak-64356 | language = Croatian | newspaper = [[Večernji list]] | publisher= [[Styria Media Group]] | author= Ivica Radoš | title = Tuđmana je za posjeta Americi 1987. trebao ubiti srpski vojni likvidator |trans-title=During his visit to America in 1987, Tuđman was supposed to have been killed by a Serbian military assassin | date = December 9, 2009 | accessdate =October 8, 2010}}</ref>
==Transition to democracy and political crisis==
In mid-1989, political parties other than the Communist Party were first allowed, starting a transition from the [[one-party system]]. A number of new parties were founded in Croatia, including the [[Croatian Democratic Union]] ({{lang-hr|Hrvatska demokratska zajednica}}) (HDZ), led by Franjo Tuđman.<ref name="Independent-Tuđman-Obituary">{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-franjo-tudjman-1132142.html |title=Obituary: Franjo Tudjman |author=Branka Magas |date=13 December 1999 |accessdate=17 October 2011 |archivedate=25 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Qmjvz7e?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-franjo-tudjman-1132142.html |df= }}</ref>
In January 1990, the [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia|Communist Party]] fragmented along national lines, with the Croatian [[Political faction|faction]] demanding a looser federation. At the 14th Extraordinary Congress of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia, on 20 January 1990, the delegations of the republics could not agree on the main issues in the Yugoslav federation. The Croatian and Slovenian delegations demanded a looser federation, while the Serbian delegation, headed by Milošević, opposed this. As a result, the Slovenian and Croatian delegates left the Congress.<ref name="Brown116"/><ref name="LondonTimes-Račan-Obituary">{{cite news | newspaper = [[The Times]] | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article1722946.ece | title = Ivica Racan | date = April 30, 2007 | accessdate=December 11, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Pauković-14Congress-2009">{{cite journal |author=Davor Pauković |publisher=Centar za politološka istraživanja |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=55640 |language=Croatian |title=Posljednji kongres Saveza komunista Jugoslavije: uzroci, tijek i posljedice raspada |trans-title=Last Congress of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia: Causes, Consequences and Course of Dissolution |date=1 June 2008 |journal=Časopis za suvremenu povijest |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=21–33 |format=PDF |issn=1847-2397 |accessdate=11 December 2010}}</ref> Having completed the [[anti-bureaucratic revolution]] in Vojvodina, Kosovo, and Montenegro, Serbia secured four out of eight federal presidency votes in 1991,<ref name="Brown116"/> and it was able to heavily influence decision-making at the federal level, because unfavorable decisions could be blocked; this rendered the governing body ineffective. This situation led to objections from other republics and calls for reform of the Yugoslav Federation.<ref name="Frucht433">[[#Frucht|Frucht (2005)]], p. 433</ref>
In February 1990, [[Jovan Rašković]] founded the [[Serb Democratic Party (Croatia)|Serb Democratic Party]] (SDS) in [[Knin]]. Its program stated that the "regional division of Croatia is outdated" and that it "does not correspond with the interest of Serb people".<ref name="g214">[[#Goldstein|Goldstein (1999)]], p. 214</ref> The party program endorsed redrawing regional and municipal lines to reflect the ethnic composition of the areas, and asserted the right of territories with a "special ethnic composition" to become autonomous. This echoed Milošević position that internal Yugoslav borders should be redrawn to permit all Serbs to live in a single country.<ref name="NYTimes-Borders-Redraw">{{cite news | newspaper = The New York Times | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE0DA1738F936A3575BC0A967958260 | title = Serbs Refuse to Negotiate in Croatia | author= Chuck Sudetic | authorlink = Chuck Sudetic | date = August 5, 1991 | accessdate=January 24, 2011}}</ref> Prominent members of the SDS were [[Milan Babić]] and [[Milan Martić]], both of whom later became high-ranking RSK officials. During his later trial, Babić would testify that there was a media campaign directed from Belgrade that portrayed the Serbs in Croatia as being threatened with genocide by the Croat majority and that he fell prey to this propaganda.<ref>[[#Babić Verdict|Babić verdict]], p. 9</ref> On 4 March 1990, a meeting of 50,000 Serbs was held at [[Petrova Gora]]. People at the rally shouted negative remarks aimed at Tuđman,<ref name="g214"/> chanted "This is Serbia",<ref name="g214"/> and expressed support for Milošević.<ref>[[#Ramet|Ramet 2006]], p. 382</ref><ref>{{cite web | publisher = [[UNCHR]] | url = http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,,QUERYRESPONSE,HRV,4562d8b62,3ae6ab78c,0.html | title = Yugoslavia: Demonstrations in Croatia and Vojvodina | date = May 1, 1990 | accessdate = December 11, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120324161438/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,,QUERYRESPONSE,HRV,4562d8b62,3ae6ab78c,0.html | archivedate = March 24, 2012 | df = }}</ref>
==Political moves and civil unrest==
In late April and early May 1990, the [[Croatian parliamentary election, 1990|first multi-party elections]] were held in Croatia, with [[Franjo Tuđman]]'s win resulting in further [[Nationalism|nationalist]] tensions.<ref name="Independent-Tuđman-Obituary">{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-franjo-tudjman-1132142.html |title=Obituary: Franjo Tudjman |author=Branka Magas |date=13 December 1999 |accessdate=17 October 2011 |archivedate=25 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Qmjvz7e?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-franjo-tudjman-1132142.html |df= }}</ref>
A tense atmosphere prevailed in 1990: on May 13, 1990, a [[Dinamo Zagreb-Red Star Belgrade riot|football game was held in Zagreb]] between [[Zagreb]]'s [[Dinamo Zagreb|Dinamo]] team and Belgrade's [[Red Star Belgrade|Crvena Zvezda]] team. The game erupted into violence between football fans and police.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dalje.com/en-sports/video--day-when-maksimir-stadium-went-up-in-flames/257791 | title=The Day When Maksimir Stadium Went up in Flames | publisher=Dalje.com | date=May 13, 2009 | accessdate=January 19, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69jJw2pP1?url=http://dalje.com/en-sports/video--day-when-maksimir-stadium-went-up-in-flames/257791 | archivedate=August 7, 2012 | df= }}</ref>
On May 30, 1990, the new [[Croatian Parliament]] held its first session. President Tuđman announced his manifesto for a new Constitution and a multitude of political, economic, and social changes, including a plan for Yugoslavia as a confederation of sovereign states.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=1765&sec=444 | language = Croatian | work = Znameniti govori iz povijesti saborovanja | title = Govor Franje Tuđmana u Saboru 30. svibnja 1990. | publisher = Croatian Parliament | accessdate = 2012-12-05}}</ref>
On July 25, 1990, Croatia made constitutional amendments that asserted and effected its sovereignty – the "Socialist" prefix was dropped from the country's name, the [[President of Croatia]] replaced the President of the Presidency, in addition to other changes.<ref name="End_of_SRH">{{cite journal |url=http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1990_07_31_610.html | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 31/1990 | language = Croatian | title = Odluka o proglašenju Amandmana LXIV. do LXXV. na Ustav Socijalističke Republike Hrvatske | date = July 25, 1990 | accessdate = July 12, 2012}}</ref> The changes in the July 1990 Croatian Constitution did not relate to the status of the Serbs, which remained identical to the one granted by the 1974 Croatian Constitution (based on the [[1974 Yugoslav Constitution]]).{{sfn|Bonacci Skenderović|Jareb|2004|pp=737–739}}{{not in citation|date=November 2017}}
Nationalist [[Serbs of Croatia|Serbs in Croatia]] boycotted the [[Sabor]] and seized control of Serb-inhabited territory, [[Log Revolution|setting up road blocks]] and voting for those areas to become [[Autonomy|autonomous]]. The [[Serb Autonomous Oblasts|Serb "autonomous oblasts"]] would soon become increasingly intent on achieving independence from Croatia.<ref name="NYTimes-Log-20AUG1990"/><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Elections_in_Europe.html?id=zUbQRQAACAAJ |title=Elections in Europe: A Data Handbook |authorlink1=Dieter Nohlen |first1=Dieter |last1=Nohlen |first2=Philip |last2=Stöver |isbn=978-3-8329-5609-7 |publisher=Nomos Verlagsgesellschaft |year=2010 |page=401 |accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes-Autonomy-AUG1990">{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world/croatia-s-serbs-declare-their-autonomy.html |author=[[Chuck Sudetic]] |title=Croatia's Serbs Declare Their Autonomy |date=2 October 1990 |accessdate=11 December 2010 |archivedate=25 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Qmswhv4?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world/croatia-s-serbs-declare-their-autonomy.html |df= }}</ref><ref name="EE-CIS-book">{{cite book |title=Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qmN95fFocsMC |pages=272–278 |isbn=978-1-85743-058-5 |year=1998 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |accessdate=16 December 2010}}</ref>
After HDZ came to power, they conducted a purge of Serbs employed in public administration, especially the police.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/143561/Croatia/223957/Croatia-in-Yugoslavia-1945-91?anchor=ref476690 | title= Croatia in Yugoslavia, 1945–91 | work= [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] | publisher= [[Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.]] | accessdate=November 18, 2010}}</ref> The Serbs of Croatia held a disproportionate number of official posts: in 1984, 22.6% of the members of the [[League of Communists of Croatia]] and 17.7% of appointed officials in Croatia were Serbs, including 28-31% in the Ministry of the Interior (the police).<ref name="Bjelajac-Žunec-239"/><ref name="Roksandić-1991"/> Whereas, in 1981, they represented 11.5%<ref name="Roksandić-1991">{{cite book | first = Drago | last = Roksandić | title = Srbi u Hrvatskoj od 15. stoljeća do naših dana | publisher = [[Vjesnik]] | location = Zagreb | year = 1991 | pages = 157–158 | quote = U razdoblju poslije 1981. godine, kada Srbi sačinjavaju 11,5 posto stanovništva, precizno 1984. godine, Vjeran Katunarić nalazi da su Srbi u Hrvatskoj 17,7 posto političkih rukovodilaca, 12,5 posto privrednih rukovodilaca, 11,9 posto pripadnika "sistemske inteligencije", [...]}}</ref> and in 1991, 12.2% of the total population of Croatia.<ref>[[#Milošević Indictment|Milošević indictment]], p. 29</ref> An even greater proportion of those posts had been held by Serbs in Croatia earlier on, which created a perception that the Serbs were guardians of the communist regime.<ref name="Bjelajac-Žunec-239">[[#Bjelajac, Žunec, Boduszynski, Draschtak, Graovac, Kent, Malli, Pavlović, Vuić|Bjelajac, Žunec, Boduszynski, Draschtak, Graovac, Kent, Malli, Pavlović, Vuić (2009)]], p. 239</ref>
President Tuđman made several clumsy remarks — such as the one from an April 16, 1990 speech<ref name="Nazor-2013"/> that he was 'glad that his wife is not a Serb'<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MRGI,,HRV,,4954ce1ec,0.html | title= World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples - Croatia: Overview | work= [[Minority Rights Group International]] | publisher= [[UNCHR]] | year=2008 | accessdate=June 29, 2012}}</ref> that was taken out of context.<ref name="Nazor-2013">{{cite web | publisher = Dnevno.hr | url = http://www.dnevno.hr/kolumne/ante-nazor/76778-laz-je-da-tudman-izbacio-srbe-iz-ustava.html | language = Croatian | title = Laž je da Tuđman 'izbacio' Srbe iz Ustava | trans-title = The lie is that Tuđman 'banned' Serbs from the Constitution | author = Ante Nazor | date = 2013-01-26 | accessdate = 2013-02-23 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141027054405/http://www.dnevno.hr/kolumne/ante-nazor/76778-laz-je-da-tudman-izbacio-srbe-iz-ustava.html | archivedate = 2014-10-27 | df = }}</ref>{{not in source|date=November 2017}} All this was deliberately distorted by Milošević's media in order to artificially spark fear that any form of an independent Croatia is a new "[[ustashe]] state": in one instance, TV Belgrade showed Tuđman shaking hands with German Chancellor [[Helmut Kohl]], accusing them of plotting to impose "a Fourth Reich".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/magazine/carving-out-a-greater-serbia.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm | title= Carving out a Greater Serbia | author= Stephen Engelberg| publisher=New York Times | date=September 1, 1991 | accessdate=June 29, 2012}}</ref> The new Tuđman government was nationalistic and insensitive towards Serbs, but did not pose a threat to them before the war.<ref>[[#Brown & Karim|Brown & Karim (1995)]], p. 119</ref>
The political crisis escalated when the Serb-populated areas attempted to form an enclave called [[Serbian Krajina]] which intended to separate from Croatia if Croatia itself attempted to separate from Yugoslavia. The Serb leadership in Krajina refused to recognize the government of the Republic of Croatia as having sovereignty over them. The crisis began in August 1990 with the [[Log Revolution]] as Croatian Serbs cut down trees and used them to block roads.<ref name="NYTimes-Log-20AUG1990">{{cite news | newspaper = The New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world/armed-serbs-guard-highways-in-croatia-during-referendum.html?ref=croatia | title = Armed Serbs Guard Highways in Croatia During Referendum | date = 20 August 1990 | accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes-Log-19AUG1990">{{cite news | newspaper = The New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/world/roads-sealed-as-yugoslav-unrest-mounts.html?ref=croatia | agency= [[Reuters]] | title = Roads Sealed as Yugoslav Unrest Mounts | date = 19 August 1990 | accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref> This hampered Croatian tourism and caused alarm in the province of [[Dalmatia]] as Croatia was hosting the [[1990 European Athletics Championships]] in [[Split (city)|Split]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Slobodna Dalmacija]]|url=http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Biznis/tabid/69/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/80962/Default.aspx|language=Croatian|title=Vrdoljak je zahtijevao: Osvojite Knin s 2000 policajaca iz Splita|trans-title=Vrdoljak demanded: Seize Knin with 2000 policemen from Split|date=28 November 2009|author=Danko Plevnik|accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref>
On December 21, 1990, a new "[[Christmas Constitution]]" was passed, that adopted a [[liberal democracy]].<ref name="december-1990">{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1990_12_56_1092.html | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 56/1990 | language = Croatian | author = [[Sabor]] | title = Ustav Republike Hrvatske | date = 22 December 1990 | accessdate = 27 December 2011}}</ref> The constitution defined Croatia as "the national state of the Croatian nation and a state of members of other nations and minorities who are its citizens: Serbs... who are guaranteed [[Social equality|equality]] with citizens of Croatian nationality...."{{sfn|Martić Verdict|2007|pp=44–49}} The status of Serbs was changed from an explicitly mentioned nation (''narod'') to a nation listed together with minorities (''narodi i manjine'').{{sfn|Bonacci Skenderović|Jareb|2004|pp=737–739}} This constitutional change was also read by the majority of Serb politicians as taking away some of the rights that the Serbs had been granted by the previous Socialist constitution, and it fuelled extremism among the Serbs of Croatia.{{sfn|Pešić|1996|p=10–11|ps=[The nations'] rights to be “constitutive” were recognized not only within their respective states, but also among their conationals inhabiting the territory of other Yugoslav republics. In some cases, these ethnic diaspora communities viewed the constitutive nature of Yugoslav nationhood as giving them the right to extend the sovereignty of their national “homeland” to the territories they inhabited. Such was the case with Serbs in Croatia, constituting 12 percent of the republic’s population in 1991. Later, this status would produce enormous problems, giving Croatian Serbs the “right” to secede from Croatia, and giving Croatia the right to deny them this status by designating them as a “minority” in its new constitution.}} This was not based on the literal reading of the former Constitution of SR Croatia, which had also treated solely Croats as a constitutive nation, saying Croatia was "national state" for Croats, "state" for Serbs and other minorities.{{sfn|Bonacci Skenderović|Jareb|2004|pp=737–739}}{{not in source|date=November 2017}}
On February 21, 1991, Croatia declared its Constitution and laws supreme to that of the SFRY,<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1991_02_8_185.html | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 8/1991 | language = Croatian | author = Croatian Parliament | title = Ustavni zakon o dopunama Ustavnog zakona za provedbu Ustava Republike Hrvatske | date = February 21, 1991 | accessdate = 12 July 2012}}</ref> and the Parliament enacted a formal resolution on the process of disassociation ({{lang-hr|razdruženje}}) from SFR Yugoslavia and possible new association with other sovereign republics.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1991_02_8_186.html | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 8/1991 | language = Croatian | author = Croatian Parliament | title = Rezolucija o prihvaćanju postupaka za razdruženje SFRJ i o mogućem udruživanju u savez suverenih republika | date = 21 February 1991 | accessdate = 12 July 2012}}</ref>
Over two hundred armed incidents involving the rebel Serbs and Croatian police were reported between August 1990 and April 1991.<ref name="Annex IV" /><ref>David C. Isby, "Yugoslavia 1991: Armed Forces in Conflict", Jane's Intelligence Review 394, 402 (September 1991)</ref>
==Independence referendum and decisions==
On May 19, 1991, the Croatian authorities held the [[Croatian independence referendum, 1991|Croatian referendum on independence]].<ref name="NN-Referendum-02May1991">{{cite journal | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 21/1991 | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1991_05_21_646.html | language = Croatian | title = Odluka o raspisu referenduma |trans-title=Decision to hold a referendum | date = 2 May 1991 | accessdate = 27 December 2011}}</ref> Serb local authorities called for a [[boycott]] of the vote, which was largely followed by Croatian Serbs.<ref name="NYTimes-Referendum-20May1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/world/croatia-votes-for-sovereignty-and-confederation.html?ref=croatia |title=Croatia Votes for Sovereignty and Confederation |first=Chuck |last=Sudetic |authorlink=Chuck Sudetic |date =20 May 1991 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> In the end, a majority of Croatians endorsed independence from Yugoslavia, with a turnout of 83.56% and the two referendum questions answered positively by 93.24% and 92.18% (resp.) of the total number of votes.<ref name="Referendum-1991-result">{{cite web |publisher=State Election Committee |url=http://www.izbori.hr/arhiva/pdf/1991/1991_Rezultati_Referendum.pdf |format=PDF |language=Croatian |title=Izviješće o provedenom referendumu |trans-title=Report on performed referendum |date=22 May 1991 |accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref>
On June 25, 1991, the country declared its independence from the SFRY, finalizing its effort to end its status as a constituent republic.<ref name="NYTimes-Declaration-26June1991">{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/world/2-yugoslav-states-vote-independence-to-press-demands.html |title=2 Yugoslav States Vote Independence To Press Demands |author=Chuck Sudetic |date=26 June 1991 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Wj75HVR?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/world/2-yugoslav-states-vote-independence-to-press-demands.html |archivedate=29 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="NN-Declaration-25June1991">{{cite journal | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 31/1991 | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1991_06_31_875.html | title = Deklaracija o proglašenju suverene i samostalne Republike Hrvatske |trans-title=Declaration on proclamation of sovereign and independent Republic of Croatia | language = Croatian | date = 25 June 1991 | accessdate = 12 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/254485.html | language = Croatian | title = Ustavna odluka Sabora Republike Hrvatske o suverenosti i samostalnosti Republike Hrvatske | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 31/1991 | date = 1991-05-26 | accessdate = 2011-06-25}}</ref> That decision of the parliament decision was partially boycotted by left-wing party deputies.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.novilist.hr/Vijesti/Hrvatska/Seks-Dio-lijevoga-bloka-odbio-glasovati-za-samostalnost | newspaper = [[Novi list]] | agency = [[HINA]] | language = Croatian | title = Šeks: Dio lijevoga bloka odbio glasovati za samostalnost | date = 25 June 2012 | accessdate = 29 November 2012}}</ref>
The [[European Economic Community]] and the [[Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe]] immediately urged both Croatia and Slovenia that they would not be recognized as independent states because of a fear of a civil war in Yugoslavia.<ref name="NYTimes-EUWarning-26June1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/world/europeans-warn-on-yugoslav-split.html?ref=croatia |title=Europeans Warn on Yugoslav Split |first=Alan |last=Riding |date=26 June 1991 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> By mid-1991, the [[Croatian War of Independence]] had already started.<ref name="NYTimes-Mobilization-6Oct1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world/shells-still-fall-on-croatian-towns-despite-truce.html?ref=croatia |title=Shells Still Fall on Croatian Towns Despite Truce |first=Chuck |last=Sudetic |authorlink= Chuck Sudetic |date=6 October 1991 |accessdate=16 December 2010}}</ref> Serb-controlled areas of Croatia were part of the three "Serb Autonomous Oblasts" later known as the [[Republic of Serbian Krajina]],<ref name="NYTimes-Iceland">{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/world/croatia-clashes-rise-mediators-pessimistic.html |title=Croatia Clashes Rise; Mediators Pessimistic |date=19 December 1991 |accessdate=29 July 2012 |archivedate=29 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69WlHzDK7?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/world/croatia-clashes-rise-mediators-pessimistic.html |df= }}</ref> bulk of which would not be under Croatian control until 1995,<ref name="NYTimes-Flash-May2">{{cite news | newspaper= The New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/02/world/croatia-hits-area-rebel-serbs-hold-crossing-un-lines.html?ref=croatia | title = CROATIA HITS AREA REBEL SERBS HOLD, CROSSING U.N. LINES | author= Roger Cohen | authorlink= Roger Cohen | date = 2 May 1995 | accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="LATimes-Storm-Complete">{{cite news | newspaper= Los Angeles Times | url = http://articles.latimes.com/1995-08-08/news/mn-32662_1_serb-refugees | title = Croats Declare Victory, End Blitz | author= Dean E. Murphy | date = 8 August 1995 | accessdate=18 December 2010}}</ref> and the remaining parts in 1998.<ref name="NYTimes-UNTAES-16Jan98" />
Croatia was first recognized as an independent state on 26 June 1991 by [[Slovenia]], which [[Independence of Slovenia|declared its own independence]] on the same day as Croatia.<ref name="NYTimes-Declaration-26June1991"/> But by 29 June, the Croatian and Slovenian authorities agreed to a three-month [[Moratorium (law)|moratorium]] on the independence declaration, in an effort to ease tensions.<ref name="NYTimes-Suspension-29June1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/world/conflict-in-yugoslavia-2-yugoslav-states-agree-to-suspend-secession-process.html?ref=croatia |title=Conflict in Yugoslavia; 2 Yugoslav States Agree to Suspend Secession Process |first=Chuck |last=Sudetic |authorlink=Chuck Sudetic |date=29 June 1991 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> The [[Brijuni Agreement]] was formally signed in a meeting of the European Community Ministerial Troika, the Yugoslav, Serbian, Slovenian and Croatian authorities on 7 July.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ucdp.uu.se/gpdatabase/peace/Yug%2019910712.pdf | publisher = University of Uppsala Department of Peace and Conflict Research database | title = Brioni Declaration | date = 8 July 1991 | accessdate = 12 July 2012}}</ref> [[Lithuania]] was the sole state that recognized Croatia on 30 July.<ref name="Recognition"/>
The [[Arbitration Commission of the Peace Conference on Yugoslavia|Badinter Arbitration Committee]] was set up by the [[Council of the European Union|Council of Ministers]] of the European Economic Community (EEC) on 27 August 1991 to provide legal advice and criteria for recognition to former Yugoslav republics.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/32133 |journal=Politička Misao |issn=0032-3241 |publisher=[[University of Zagreb]], Faculty of Political Sciences |author=Sandro Knezović |language=Croatian |title=Europska politika u vrijeme disolucije jugoslavenske federacije |trans-title=European Politics at the Time of the Dissolution of the Yugoslav Federation |pages=109–131 |volume=43 |issue=3 |date=February 2007 |accessdate=18 June 2012|format=PDF}}</ref> The five-member commission consisted of presidents of [[constitutional court]]s in the EEC.<ref name="pellet"/>
[[File:Zgrada INA Naftaplin 1.JPG|right|thumb|[[INA (company)|INA]] building on [[Pavao Šubić Avenue|Šubićeva Avenue]], Zagreb was selected for security reasons as the venue for parliament's declaration of independence on 8 October 1991]] On 7 October, the eve of expiration of the moratorium, the [[SFR Yugoslav Air Force|Yugoslav Air Force]] [[Bombing of Banski dvori|attacked Banski dvori]], the main [[Croatian Government|government]] building in [[Zagreb]].<ref name="NYTimes-BanskiDvoriRaid-8Oct1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/world/yugoslav-planes-attack-croatian-presidential-palace.html |title=Yugoslav Planes Attack Croatian Presidential Palace |date=8 October 1991 |accessdate=13 December 2010}}</ref><ref name="LATimes-BanskiDvoriRaid-8Oct1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-10-08/news/mn-151_1_civil-war |title=Croatia Leader's Palace Attacked |date=8 October 1991 |first= Carol J. |last=Williams |accessdate=23 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 October 1991, the moratorium expired, and the Croatian Parliament severed all remaining ties with Yugoslavia.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1991_10_53_1265.html |journal=[[Narodne novine]] |issue=53/1991 |language=Croatian |title=Odluka [Klasa: 021-03/91-05/07] |author=[[Croatian Parliament]] |date=8 October 1991 |accessdate=12 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923040416/http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1991_10_53_1265.html |archivedate=23 September 2009 |df= }}</ref> That particular session of the parliament was held in the [[INA (company)|INA]] building on [[Pavao Šubić Avenue]] in Zagreb due to security concerns provoked by recent Yugoslav [[Airstrike|air raid]];<ref>{{cite web |publisher=[[Sabor]] |language=Croatian |url=http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=24723 |title=Govor predsjednika Hrvatskog sabora Luke Bebića povodom Dana neovisnosti |trans-title=Speech of Luka Bebić, Speaker of the Croatian Parliament on occasion of the Independence day |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2011}}</ref> Specifically, it was feared that the Yugoslav Air Force might attack the parliament building.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=[[Glas Slavonije]] |language=Croatian |url=http://www.glas-slavonije.hr/mvijest.asp?rub=3&ID_VIJESTI=11436 |title=Dvadeset godina slobodne Hrvatske |trans-title=Twenty years of free Croatia |date=8 October 2011 |author=Dražen Boroš |accessdate=29 December 2011}}</ref> This decision was reached unanimously in the Parliament, and the only parliamentary deputies missing were some from the Serb parties that had been absent since early 1991.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://dnevnik.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/seks-odlukom-od-8-listopada-1991-konacno-utvrdzena-neovisnost.html | language = Croatian | publisher = [[Nova TV (Croatia)|Nova TV]]/Dnevnik.hr | title = Šeks: Odlukom od 8. listopada 1991. konačno utvrđena neovisnost | date = 7 October 2011 | accessdate = 29 November 2012}}</ref>
==General recognition== {{see also|International recognition of Croatia}}
[[Germany]] advocated quick recognition of Croatia, in order to stop ongoing violence in Serb-inhabited areas, with [[Helmut Kohl]] requesting recognition in the [[Bundestag]] on 4 September. Kohl's position was opposed by [[France]], the [[United Kingdom]]<ref>Lukač, Morana (2013). [https://books.google.com/books?id=YUfgnAEACAAJ Germany's Recognition of Croatia and Slovenia: Portrayal of the events in the British and the US press.] Saarbrücken: AV Akademikerverlag. {{ISBN|978-3639468175}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=June 2013}}, and the [[Netherlands]], but the countries agreed to pursue a common approach by following Germany's unilateral action. On 10 October, two days after the Croatian Parliament confirmed the declaration of independence, the EEC decided to postpone any decision to recognize Croatia for two months. German foreign minister [[Hans Dietrich Genscher]] later wrote that the EEC decided to recognize Croatian independence in two months if the war had not ended by then. With the war still ongoing when the deadline expired, Germany presented its decision to recognize Croatia as its policy and duty. Germany's position was supported by [[Italy]] and [[Denmark]]. France and the UK attempted to prevent German recognition by drafting a [[United Nations]] resolution requesting that no country take unilateral actions which could worsen the situation in Yugoslavia.<ref name="Lucarelli-2000"/>
[[File:Robert Badinter.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Robert Badinter]] presided over the [[Arbitration Commission of the Conference on Yugoslavia]]]]
Starting in late November 1991, the Badinter Commission rendered a series of ten opinions. The Commission stated, among other things, that Yugoslavia was in the process of dissolution, and that the internal boundaries of Yugoslav republics could not be altered unless freely agreed upon.<ref name="pellet">{{cite journal|first=Allain |last=Pellet |title=The Opinions of the Badinter Arbitration Committee: A Second Breath for the Self-Determination of Peoples |journal=European Journal of International Law |year=1992 |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=178–185 |format=PDF |url=http://207.57.19.226/journal/Vol3/No1/art12-13.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529223410/http://207.57.19.226/journal/Vol3/No1/art12-13.pdf |archivedate=2011-05-29 |df= }}</ref> Factors in the preservation of Croatia's pre-war borders were the Yugoslav federal constitutional amendments of 1971 and 1974, granting that sovereign rights were exercised by the federal units, and that the federation had only the authority specifically transferred to it by the constitution.<ref name="Rich" /><ref name="PravST-Ustav-1974">{{cite journal |last1= Čobanov |first1=Saša |last2=Rudolf |first2=Davorin |publisher=[[University of Split]] Faculty of Law |url=http://www.pravst.hr/zbornik.php?p=25&s=170 |language=Croatian |title=Jugoslavija: unitarna država ili federacija povijesne težnje srpskoga i hrvatskog naroda – jedan od uzroka raspada Jugoslavije |trans-title=Yugoslavia: a unitary state or federation of historic efforts of Serbian and Croatian nations—one of the causes of the breakup of Yugoslavia |year=2009 |journal=Zbornik radova Pravnog fakulteta u Splitu |volume=46 |issue=2 |issn= 1847-0459 |accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref> The borders had been defined by demarcation commissions in 1947.<ref name="Kraljević-Razgraničenje-1947">{{cite journal |first=Egon |last=Kraljević |publisher=[[Croatian State Archives]] |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=41791|pages=121–130 |language=Croatian |title=Prilog za povijest uprave: Komisija za razgraničenje pri Predsjedništvu Vlade Narodne Republike Hrvatske 1945.-1946 |trans-title=Contribution to the history of public administration: commission for the boundary demarcation at the government's presidency of the People's Republic of Croatia, 1945–1946 |date=November 2007 |journal= Arhivski vjesnik |volume=50 |issue=50 |format=PDF |issn= 0570-9008 |accessdate=20 June 2012}}</ref>
Ultimately, France and the UK backed down during the [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] debate on the matter on 14 December, when Germany appeared determined to defy the UN resolution. On 17 December, the EEC formally agreed to grant Croatia diplomatic recognition on 15 January 1992, on the basis of its request and a positive opinion of the Badinter Arbitration Commission.<ref name="Lucarelli-2000">{{cite book|title=Europe and the breakup of Yugoslavia: a political failure in search of a scholarly explanation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bcxv1eVCyhIC |isbn=978-90-411-1439-6 |first=Sonia |last=Lucarelli |publisher=[[Martinus Nijhoff Publishers]] |year=2000 |accessdate=27 December 2011 |pages=125–129}}</ref>
In its Opinion No. 5 on the specific matter of Croatian independence, the Commission ruled that Croatia's independence should not yet be recognized, because the new [[Constitution of Croatia|Croatian Constitution]] did not incorporate protections for minorities required by European Community. In response to this decision, the President of Croatia [[Franjo Tuđman]] wrote to Robert Badinter, giving assurances that this deficit would be remedied.<ref name="Rich-48-49">{{cite journal|author=Roland Rich |title=Recognition of States: The Collapse of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union |journal=European Journal of International Law |year=1993 |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=48–49 |url=http://www.ejil.org/pdfs/4/1/1207.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=November 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421143955/http://www.ejil.org/pdfs/4/1/1207.pdf |archivedate=April 21, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
[[Ukraine]] and [[Latvia]] were the first to react by recognizing Croatian independence in the second week of December.<ref name="Recognition"/> The following week, [[Iceland]] and Germany recognized it, on 19 December 1991, as the first western European countries to do so.<ref name="Recognition">{{cite web |publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)]] |url=http://www.mvep.hr/en/foreign-politics/bilateral-relations1/date-of-recognition-and-establishment-of-diplomatic-relations/ |title=Date of Recognition and Establishment of Diplomatic Relation |accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref>
In response to the decisions of the Badinter Commission, the RSK formally declared its separation from Croatia on 19 December, but its statehood and independence were not recognized internationally.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L7UOyPGYBkwC |title=Statehood and the law of self-determination |isbn=978-90-411-1890-5 |publisher=[[Martinus Nijhoff Publishers]] |year=2002 |pages=79–81 |accessdate=28 December 2011}}</ref> On 26 December, Yugoslavia announced plans for a smaller state, which could include the territory captured from Croatia during the war.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/world/serb-led-presidency-drafts-plan-for-new-and-smaller-yugoslavia.html?ref=croatia |title=Serb-Led Presidency Drafts Plan For New and Smaller Yugoslavia |date=27 December 1991 |accessdate=28 December 2011}}</ref> This plan was rejected by the [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=United Nations |url=http://daccess-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N95/766/51/PDF/N9576651.pdf?OpenElement |format=PDF |title=A/RES/49/43 The situation in the occupied territories of Croatia |date=9 February 1995 |accessdate=28 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519235642/http://daccess-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N95/766/51/PDF/N9576651.pdf?OpenElement |archivedate=19 May 2015 |df= }}</ref>
Three more countries decided to recognize Croatia before the EEC-scheduled date of January 15: [[Estonia]], the [[Holy See]], and [[San Marino]].<ref name="Recognition"/> The European Economic Community finally granted Croatia [[diplomatic recognition]] on 15 January 1992, and the United Nations did so in May 1992.<ref name="NYTimes-Germany-23Dec91">{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/world/slovenia-and-croatia-get-bonn-s-nod.html |title=Slovenia and Croatia Get Bonn's Nod |author=[[Stephen Kinzer]] |date=24 December 1991 |accessdate=29 July 2012 |archivedate=29 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69WmZTuSS?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/world/slovenia-and-croatia-get-bonn-s-nod.html |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT-UN-membership">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/23/world/3-ex-yugoslav-republics-are-accepted-into-un.html |title=3 Ex-Yugoslav Republics Are Accepted Into U.N. |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |author=[[Paul L. Montgomery]] |date=23 May 1992 |accessdate=29 July 2012 |archivedate=29 July 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69WnEWOSK?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/23/world/3-ex-yugoslav-republics-are-accepted-into-un.html |df= }}</ref>
==Aftermath==
In the period following the declaration of independence, the war escalated, with the [[Battle of Vukovar|sieges of Vukovar]]<ref name="NYT-Vukovar-Captured">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world/croats-concede-danube-town-s-loss.html?ref=croatia |title=Croats Concede Danube Town's Loss |first=Chuck |last=Sudetic |authorlink=Chuck Sudetic |date=18 November 1991 |accessdate=15 December 2010}}</ref> and [[Siege of Dubrovnik|Dubrovnik]],<ref name="NYTimes-Dubrovnik-9Nov1991">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/09/world/old-city-totters-in-yugoslav-siege.html?ref=croatia |first=David |last=Binder |title=Old City Totters in Yugoslav Siege |date=9 November 1991 |accessdate=16 December 2010}}</ref> and fighting elsewhere, until a [[Sarajevo Agreement|ceasefire of 3 January 1992]] led to stabilization and a significant reduction of violence.<ref name="NYTimes-Jan3-Ceasefire">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/03/world/yugoslav-factions-agree-to-un-plan-to-halt-civil-war.html?ref=croatia |title=Yugoslav Factions Agree to U.N. Plan to Halt Civil War |first=Chuck |last=Sudetic |authorlink=Chuck Sudetic |date=3 January 1992 |accessdate=16 December 2010}}</ref>
With the end of 1991, the second Yugoslavia [[Dissolution of Yugoslavia|effectively ceased to exist as a state]], with the prime minister [[Ante Marković]] and president of the presidency [[Stjepan Mesić]] resigning in December 1991,<ref>{{cite book|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4CrpzRJCbckC|title=Central and South-Eastern Europe 2003|publisher= Routledge|year=2002|isbn= 9781857431360|accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref> and [[caretaker government]] representing it until the country's formal dissolution in April 1992.<ref>{{cite book|page=422|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mButzsYUurkC|title=The Demise of Yugoslavia: A Political Memoir|author=[[Stjepan Mesić]]|publisher=Central European University Press|year=2004|isbn= 9789639241817|accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref>
The war effectively ended in August 1995 with a decisive victory for Croatia as a result of [[Operation Storm]].<ref name="LATimes-Storm-Complete" /> Present day borders of Croatia were established when the remaining [[Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Syrmia (1995-1998)|Serb-held areas of eastern Slavonia]] were restored to Croatia pursuant to the [[Erdut Agreement]] of November 1995, with the process concluded in January 1998.<ref name="NYTimes-UNTAES-16Jan98">{{cite news|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world/an-ethnic-morass-is-returned-to-croatia.html |title=An Ethnic Morass Is Returned to Croatia |author=[[Chris Hedges]] |date=16 January 1998 |accessdate=18 December 2010 |archivedate=4 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69fNS26LX?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world/an-ethnic-morass-is-returned-to-croatia.html?ref=croatia |df= }}</ref>
==Legacy==
Since 2002, 8 October is celebrated as [[Independence Day (Croatia)|Croatia's Independence Day]], while 25 June is the [[Statehood Day (Croatia)|Statehood Day]].<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2001_11_96_1614.html | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 96/2001 | language = Croatian | title = Zakon o izmjenama i dopuni Zakona o blagdanima, spomendanu i neradnim danima u Republici Hrvatskoj | date = November 7, 2001 | accessdate = July 12, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991">{{cite web|work=Official web site of the Croatian Parliament|publisher=Sabor|url=http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=20091&sec=2462|title=Ceremonial session of the Croatian Parliament on the occasion of the Day of Independence of the Republic of Croatia|date=7 October 2004|accessdate=29 July 2012|archivedate=29 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Wk9bFY8?url=http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=20091&sec=2462|df=}}</ref> 30 May, marking the day when the first democratic parliament was constituted in 1990, used to be commemorated as the Statehood Day.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/tri-rodendana-svaki-datum-ima-povijesno-znacenje-hrvatsku-clanak-303723 | language = Croatian | newspaper = [[Večernji list]] | title = Dan državnosti - Tri rođendana: Svaki datum ima povijesno značenje za Hrvatsku | date = 24 June 2011 | accessdate = 25 June 2011}}</ref>
Although it is not a public holiday, 15 January is marked as the day Croatia won international recognition by Croatian media and politicians.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Croatian Radiotelevision]]|title=Obilježena obljetnica priznanja |language=Croatian |url=http://www.hrt.hr/index.php?id=48&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=101487&cHash=164234a438 |trans-title=Recognition Anniversary Marked |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=29 December 2011}}</ref> On the day's 10th anniversary in 2002, the [[Croatian National Bank]] minted a 25 [[Croatian kuna|kuna]] [[commemorative coin]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Croatian National Bank]] |url=http://www.hnb.hr/novcan/kovanice/e25kuna.htm |title=Commemorative 25 Kuna Coins in Circulation |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=29 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111216132034/http://www.hnb.hr/novcan/kovanice/e25kuna.htm |archivedate=16 December 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Symbols==
{{Gallery | title = Croatian coat of arms and flag used in 1990 and 1991 | width = 140 | height = 100 | align= center |File:Flag of Croatia (white chequy).svg | Flag used June 27, – December 21, 1990<ref>{{cite video | people= | date=1990-06-20 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V8ath2k53vo | title=SRH preimenovana u RH |trans-title=Socialist Republic of Croatia is renamed to Republic of Croatia | medium=Motion picture, [[TV kalendar]] | location=[[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] | publisher=[[Croatian Radiotelevision]]}}</ref> |File:Coat of arms of Croatia (white chequy).svg | Coat of arms used June 27, – December 21, 1990 |File:Flag of Croatia.svg | [[Flag of Croatia|Flag]] used from December 21, 1990 |File:Coat of arms of Croatia.svg | [[Coat of Arms of Croatia|Coat of arms]] used from December 21, 1990 }}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Sources== *{{cite book | editor1-first= Charles W. | editor1-last= Ingrao | editor2-first= Thomas Allan | editor2-last= Emmert | title= Confronting the Yugoslav Controversies: a Scholars' Initiative | year= 2009 | publisher= [[Purdue University Press]] | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=t0nYdgFrdG8C | isbn=1-55753-533-7 | chapter= The War in Croatia, 1991–1995 | ref= Bjelajac, Žunec, Boduszynski, Draschtak, Graovac, Kent, Malli, Pavlović, Vuić| last1= Bjelajac | first1= Mile | last2= Žunec | first2= Ozren |author3=Mieczyslaw Boduszynski |author4=Raphael Draschtak |author5=Igor Graovac |author6=Sally Kent |author7=Rüdiger Malli |author8=Srdja Pavlović |author9=Jason Vuić | chapterurl= http://www.cla.purdue.edu/academic/history/facstaff/Ingrao/si/Team_7_Full_Text_Report.pdf | format= PDF}} *{{cite web|publisher= International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia |url= http://www.icty.org/x/cases/slobodan_milosevic/ind/en/ind_cro010927.pdf |title=The Prosecutor of the Tribunal against Slobodan Milošević (IT-02-54) - Indictment|date=October 22, 2002| ref=Milošević Indictment |accessdate=October 18, 2010}} *{{cite book|ref=Brown & Karim| last1=Brown|last2=Karim| first1= Cynthia |first2=Farhad| title=Playing the "Communal Card": Communal Violence and Human Rights|year=1995|location=New York City| publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]| isbn=9781564321527}} *{{cite book | ref=Frucht| last=Frucht | first=Richard C. | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lVBB1a0rC70C | title=Eastern Europe: An Introduction to the People, Lands, and Culture | year=2005 | publisher=ABC-CLIO |location=Santa Barbara, California| isbn=978-1-57607-800-6}} *{{cite journal | ref = harv | publisher = [[United States Institute for Peace]] | url = http://www.usip.org/publications/serbian-nationalism-and-origins-yugoslav-crisis | title = Serbian Nationalism and the Origins of the Yugoslav Crisis | first = Vesna | last = Pešić | authorlink=Vesna Pešić | journal= Peaceworks | issue= 8 |date=April 1996 | accessdate = November 29, 2012}} *{{cite web | ref = {{harvid|Martić Verdict|2007}} | title=The Prosecutor vs. Milan Martic - Judgement |url=http://www.icty.org/x/cases/martic/tjug/en/070612.pdf |publisher=International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia |date=June 12, 2007 |accessdate=August 11, 2010}} *{{cite journal | ref = harv | first1 = Dunja | last1 = Bonacci Skenderović | first2 = Mario | last2 = Jareb | title = Hrvatski nacionalni simboli između negativnih stereotipa i istine | journal = Journal of Contemporary History | volume = 36 | number = 2 | pp = 731–760 |date=July 2004 | publisher = Croatian Institute of History | issn = 0590-9597 | url = http://hrcak.srce.hr/103307?lang=en | accessdate = December 29, 2013}} *[http://croatia.org/crown/content_images/2018/Croatia_1990-2018.pdf Croatia since Independence 1990-2018]

revision.comment: sp.: [[International Labour Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{rights}}{{Indigenous rights}} [[File:Whitlam Lingiari Image 3.jpg|thumb|On 26 August 1975 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam handed a leasehold title to land at Daguragu (Wattie Creek) to Vincent Lingiari, representative of the Gurindji people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://indigenousrights.net.au/land_rights|title=Collaborating for Indigenous Rights Home|last=Australia|first=National Museum of|website=indigenousrights.net.au|access-date=2016-05-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505095100/http://indigenousrights.net.au/land_rights|archivedate=2016-05-05|df=}}</ref>]] '''Indigenous rights''' are those [[rights]] that exist in recognition of the specific condition of the [[indigenous peoples]]. This includes not only the most basic human rights of physical survival and integrity, but also the [[Indigenous land rights|preservation of their land]], [[Indigenous language|language]], [[Ethnic religion|religion]], and other elements of cultural heritage that are a part of their existence as a people. This can be used as an expression for advocacy of social organizations or form a part of the national law in establishing the relation between a government and the right of [[self-determination]] among the indigenous people living within its borders, or in international law as a protection against violation by actions of governments or groups of private interests.
== Definition and historical background ==
The indigenous rights belong to those who, being indigenous peoples, are defined by being the original people of a land that has been conquested and [[colonialism|colonized]] by outsiders.<ref name="Lindholt 6666">{{cite book |title=Human Rights in Development Yearbook 2003: Human Rights and Local/living Law |last=Lindholt |first=Lone |publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers |year=2005 |isbn=90-04-13876-5}}</ref><ref name="Gray 2003">{{cite book |title=Indigenous Rights and Development: Self-Determination in an Amazonian Community |last=Gray |first=Andrew | authorlink = Andrew Gray (anthropologist)|publisher=Berghahn Books |year=2003 |isbn=1-57181-837-5}}</ref><ref name="Keal 2003">{{cite book |title=European Conquest and the Rights of Indigenous Peoples: The Moral Backwardness of International Society |last=Keal |first=Paul |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2003 |isbn=0-521-82471-0}}</ref><ref name=Lawandanthropology>{{cite book |title=Law & Anthropology: "Indigenous Peoples, Constitutional States And Treaties Of Other Constructive Arrangements Between Indigenous Peoples And States" |last=Kuppe |first=Rene |publisher=Brill Academic Publishers |year=2005 |isbn=90-04-14244-4}}</ref> Exactly who is a part of the indigenous peoples is disputed, but can broadly be understood in relation to colonialism. When we speak of indigenous peoples we speak of those pre-colonial societies that face a specific threat from this phenomenon of occupation, and the relation that these societies have with the colonial powers. The exact definition of who are the indigenous people, and the consequent state of rightsholders, varies. It is considered both to be bad to be too inclusive as it is to be non-inclusive.<ref name=Lawandanthropology/><ref name="culturalsurvival.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.culturalsurvival.org/ourpublications/voices/article/recognizing-indigenous-peoples-human-rights|title=RECOGNIZING INDIGENOUS PEOPLES' HUMAN RIGHTS|work=[[Cultural Survival]]|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111014153/http://www.culturalsurvival.org/ourpublications/voices/article/recognizing-indigenous-peoples-human-rights|archivedate=11 January 2012|df=}}</ref> In the context of modern indigenous people of European colonial powers, the recognition of indigenous rights can be traced to at least the period of [[Renaissance]]. Along with the justification of colonialism with a higher purpose for both the colonists and colonized, some voices expressed concern over the way indigenous peoples were treated and the effect it had on their societies.<ref>{{cite book |title=Indigenous Peoples in International Law |last=Anaya |first=S. James | authorlink = James Anaya |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2004 |isbn=0-19-517350-3}}</ref> In the [[Spanish Empire]], the crown established the General Indian Court in [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico|Mexico]] and in [[Indigenous peoples in Peru|Peru]], with jurisdiction over cases involving the indigenous and aimed at protecting Indians from ill-treatment. Indians' access to the court was enabled by a small tax which paid for legal aides.<ref>[[Woodrow Borah]], ''The General Indian Court of Mexico and the Legal Aides of the Half-Real''. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press 1983.</ref><ref>Woodrow Borah, "Juzgado General de Indios del Perú o juzgado particular de indios de El Cercado de Lima." ''[[Revista chilena de historia del derecho]]'', no. 6 (1970): 129-142.</ref>
The issue of indigenous rights is also associated with other levels of human struggle. Due to the close relationship between indigenous peoples' cultural and economic situations and their environmental settings, indigenous rights issues are linked with concerns over environmental change and [[sustainable development]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ciesin.columbia.edu/TG/PI/RIGHTS/indig.html|title=Rights of Indigenous Peoples|publisher=|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923203406/http://www.ciesin.columbia.edu/TG/PI/RIGHTS/indig.html|archivedate=23 September 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcl.american.edu/hrbrief/v2i3/suagee23.htm|title=Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities for the Natural World|publisher=|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125213107/https://www.wcl.american.edu/hrbrief/v2i3/suagee23.htm|archivedate=25 November 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.uoregon.edu/org/jell/docs/211/OEL105.pdf|title=University of Oregon School of Law|publisher=|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303183105/https://law.uoregon.edu/org/jell/docs/211/OEL105.pdf|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}}</ref> According to scientists and organizations like the [[Rainforest Foundation Fund|Rainforest Foundation]], the struggle for indigenous peoples is essential for solving the problem of reducing carbon emission, and approaching the threat on both cultural and biological diversity in general.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2008/10/indigenous-rights-reduced-emissions-deforestation.php|title=Indigenous Rights Crucial To Reducing Carbon Emissions from Deforestation|work=[[TreeHugger]]|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820193616/http://www.treehugger.com/files/2008/10/indigenous-rights-reduced-emissions-deforestation.php|archivedate=20 August 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Conservation through cultural survival: indigenous peoples and protected areas |last=Stevens |first=Stanley |publisher=Island Press |year=1997 |isbn=1-55963-449-9}}</ref><ref name=SOWIP>United Nations, [https://web.archive.org/web/20100215113446/http://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/SOWIP_web.pdf State of The World's Indigenous Peoples] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215113446/http://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/SOWIP_web.pdf |date=February 15, 2010 }} – [[UNPFII]] report, First Issue, 2009</ref>
==Representation== The [[Human rights|rights]], claims and even identity of indigenous peoples are apprehended, acknowledged and observed quite differently from government to government. Various organizations exist with charters to in one way or another promote (or at least acknowledge) indigenous aspirations, and indigenous societies have often banded together to form bodies which jointly seek to further their communal interests.
=== International organizations === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Indigenous rights organizations.PNG|right|thumb|Organizations that struggle for indigenous rights {{ifdc|Indigenous rights organizations.PNG|log=2013 December 27}}]] --> There are several non-governmental civil society movements, networks, indigenous and non-indigenous organizations whose founding mission is to protect [[Indigenous rights to land along rivers|indigenous rights, including land rights]].<ref name=earthpeoples>[http://earthpeoples.org/missionstatement/missionenglish.html/About Earth Peoples]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> These organizations, networks and groups underline that the problems that indigenous peoples are facing is the lack of recognition that they are entitled to live the way they choose, and lack of the right to their lands and territories. Their mission is to protect the rights of indigenous peoples without states imposing their ideas of "development".<ref name=survivalinternational>{{cite web|url=http://www.survival-international.org/info|title=About us|author=Survival International|publisher=|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917124100/http://www.survival-international.org/info|archivedate=17 September 2009|df=}}</ref> These groups say that each indigenous culture is differentiated, rich of religious believe systems, way of life, substenance and arts, and that the root of problem would be the interference with their way of living by state's disrespect to their rights, as well as the invasion of traditional lands by multinational cooperations and small businesses for exploitation of natural resources. <ref name="International Indian Treaty Council">{{cite web|url=http://www.treatycouncil.org//info|title=International Indian Treaty Council|work=iitc.org|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
===United Nations===
Indigenous peoples and their interests are represented in the United Nations primarily through the mechanisms of the [[Working Group on Indigenous Populations]] (WGIP). In April 2000 the [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights]] adopted a resolution to establish the [[United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues]] (PFII) as an advisory body to the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council|Economic and Social Council]] with a mandate to review indigenous issues.
In late December 2004, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] proclaimed 2005–2014 to be the ''Second International Decade of the World's Indigenous People''. The main goal of the new decade will be to strengthen international cooperation around resolving the problems faced by indigenous peoples in areas such as culture, education, health, human rights, the environment, and social and economic development.
In September 2007, after a process of preparations, discussions and negotiations stretching back to 1982, the General Assembly adopted the [[Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples]]. The non-binding declaration outlines the individual and collective rights of indigenous peoples, as well as their rights to identity, culture, language, employment, health, education and other issues. Four nations with significant indigenous populations voted against the declaration: the United States, Canada, New Zealand and Australia. All four have since then changed their vote in favour. Eleven nations abstained: [[Azerbaijan]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Bhutan]], [[Burundi]], [[Colombia]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Kenya]], [[Nigeria]], Russia, [[Samoa]] and [[Ukraine]]. Thirty-four nations did not vote, while the remaining 143 nations voted for it.
===ILO 169=== {{main|ILO 169}}
ILO 169 is a convention of the [[International Labour Organization]]. Once ratified by a state, it is meant to work as a law protecting tribal people's rights. There are twenty-two physical survival and integrity, but also the [[Indigenous land rights|preservation of their land]], [[Indigenous language|language]] [[Ethnic religion|and religion]] rights. The ILO is represents indigenous rights as they are the organisation that enforced instruments the deal with indigenous rights exclusively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/global/topics/equality-and-discrimination/indigenous-and-tribal-peoples/lang--en/index.htm|title=Indigenous and tribal peoples|website=www.ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2016-05-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508035237/http://www.ilo.org/global/topics/equality-and-discrimination/indigenous-and-tribal-peoples/lang--en/index.htm|archivedate=2016-05-08|df=}}</ref>
===Organization of American States=== Since 1997, the nations of the Organization of American States have been discussing draft versions of a proposed American Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.<ref>Website of the [http://www.cidh.oas.org/indigenas/chap.2g.htm Proposed American Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525222059/http://www.cidh.oas.org/indigenas/chap.2g.htm |date=2013-05-25 }}</ref> "The draft declaration is currently one of the most important processes underway with regard to indigenous rights in the Americas"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iwgia.org/human-rights/regional-bodies-and-mechanisms/organisation-of-american-states|title=Organisation of American States|last=Hansen|first=Jens Søgaard|website=www.iwgia.org|access-date=2016-05-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604093032/http://www.iwgia.org/human-rights/regional-bodies-and-mechanisms/organisation-of-american-states|archivedate=2016-06-04|df=}}</ref> as mentioned by the International Work Group for Indigenous Affairs.
===Individual states=== ====Canada==== In Canada "Aboriginal rights" ({{lang-fr|droits ancestraux}}) are those rights that indigenous peoples enjoy as a result of their ancestors' long occupancy of the land, for example the right to hunt and fish a particular territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1100100028605/1100100028606|title=Aboriginal Rights|first=Government of Canada; Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada; Communications|last=Branch|date=|website=www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180417130624/http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1100100028605/1100100028606|archivedate=17 April 2018|df=}}</ref> These are distinct from "[[treaty rights]]" which are enumerated in specific agreements between indigenous groups and the state. Both treaty rights and Aboriginal rights are protected by [[Section 35]] of the [[Canadian constitution of 1982]].
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Bioregionalism]] *[[Bumiputra]] *[[Cultural diversity]] *[[Cultural imperialism]] *[[Ethnic nepotism]] *[[Indigenous land rights]] *''[[Jus sanguinis]]'' *[[Minority rights]] *[[Nativism (politics)|Nativism]] *[[Survival International]] *[[Xenophobia]] {{div col end|3}}

Perkins *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110309050125/http://www-personal.arts.usyd.edu.au/duncan.ivison/indigenousrights.pdf Indigenous Rights] – International Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences, 2nd Edition *[https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/en/drip.html United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples] *[https://web.archive.org/all/20111031202527/http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/cgi-lex/convde.pl?C169 ILO Convention 169 (full text)] - Current international law on indigenous peoples *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100215113446/http://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/SOWIP_web.pdf State of The World's Indigenous Peoples] – UN report, First Issue, 2009 *[https://www.scribd.com/doc/39884822/Norman-Lewis-article-which-led-to-the-founding-of-Survival-International Genocide] Lewis, Norman, February 1969 - Article that led to the foundation of several prominent indigenous rights organizations * [http://www.rainforestfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Conservation_and_Community_Rights.pdf Conservation and Community Rights: Lessons from Mesoamerica]

{{advert|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Institute for International Research | logo = IIRLogo.png | type = an [[Informa]] business | foundation = [[London]] (1973) | location_city = | industry = Events, [[Exhibitions]], [[Convention (meeting)|Conferences]], [[Training]], [[Executive Development]] | key_people = Debra Chipman, President & CEO, IIRUSA | subsid = IIR Australia
IIR Austria
IIR Executive Development
IIR Finance
IIR Middle East
IIR Netherlands
IIR Spain
IIR USA | homepage = }} '''Institute for International Research''', Inc. ('''IIR''') is a subsidiary of [[Informa]] Plc. It grew from its founding to 1973 to become one of the world's largest [[Convention (meeting)|conference]] providers. It has been part of the Informa Group since 2005. ==Overview== The company was started by [[Irvine Laidlaw, Baron Laidlaw]] in 1973 and sold to [[Informa]] for a reported GBP 768 million in 2005.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article3822710.ece|title=Tory peer Lord Laidlaw seeks treatment for sex addiction|publisher=The Sunday Times|date=27 April 2008|accessdate=2008-04-27}}Reece, Damian (2 June 2005). [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/lord-laidlaw-sells-iir-events-firm-for-14bn-6144995.html Lord Laidlaw sells IIR events firm for $1.4bn], ''[[The Independent]]''(23 August 2005). [http://www2.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-08/23/content_471363.htm Small is bigger for expo organizer], ''[[China Daily]]'' Irvine Laidlaw began IIR by producing newsletters out of a base in Hong Kong. ==Operations== In 1989, IIR Inc. in the United States acquired institutions in order to enter the seminar and training business. Acquisitions included training organisers such as [[ESI International]], [[Achieve Global]] Huthwaite followed by Omega Performance and Communispond. Debra Chipman is the current{{When|date=February 2012}} president and chief executive officer of the Institute for International Research, Inc, which operates as a subsidiary of IIR Ltd. Many IIR conferences, workshops and training courses are conducted in Europe each year. These cover many topics including general management, finance, banking and energy. IIR has been active in Austria since 1992. Annual congresses held in Austria include ''Epcon"''(energy), ''tel.con'' (telecommunications industry), ''Pulse'' (health), ''Course'' (banking sector) and the ''ÖVT'' (insurance industry). IIR has been operating in Germany since 1989 with 200 employees, 14 divisions and about 2000 events. Starting from 1999, Austria developed the [[Central and Eastern Europe|CEE]] region for IIR, with offices in Poland (Warsaw), Czech Republic (Prague) and Hungary (Budapest). IIR online regional sites include IIR Austria,[http://www.iir.at/ IIR: IIR Österreich - Berufliche Weiterbildung mit IIR Österreich: Seminare, Konferenzen, Kongresse, Trainings] IIR Australia[http://www.iir.com.au Welcome to IIR Conferences] IIR North America,[http://www.iirusa.com/ IIR USA - Events Deliver Business] IIR Middle East,[http://www.iirme.com/ Conferences, Training, Managed Events, Exhibitions in Dubai - Home] IIR Telecoms[http://iir-telecoms.com/ IIR Telecoms & Technology] and Informa plc.[http://www.informa.com/ Informa.com - Home] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070702092252/http://www.usabilityprofessionals.org/upa_publications/upa_voice/volumes/2006/december/upa_market_research_event_2006.html The Usability Professionals' Association – The UPA Voice – Institute for International Research (IIR) and the UPA Connection: The Market Research Event 2006] * [http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/minist/health-sante/speeches-discours/1996_04_01_e.html Government of Canada, Health Canada – Institute for International Research Conference – Speaking Notes for David C. Dingwall, Minister of Health, The Toronto Hilton Hotel, Toronto, 1 April 1996]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.kenyon.com/events/detail_event.aspx?event_id=321555305 Kenyon & Kenyon - Events - Institute for International Research's 7th Annual Generic Drugs Summit] "Steven J. Lee, Ph.D., partner in our New York Office, will be participating in a panel entitled "The Effect of Proposed Patent Reform Legislation on Hatch-Waxman Litigation" at the Institute for International Research's 7th Annual Generic Drugs Summit in Washington, D.C." * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070519062929/http://center.spoke.com/info/cNAti/InstituteForInternationalResearchInc Spoke – Institute for International Research] {{Informa}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} [[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Business services companies established in 1973]] [[Category:1973 establishments in England]]
