page.title: The Fertility Transition in Iran: Revolution and Reproduction

revision.text:
{{short description|2009 book by [[Meimanat Hosseini-Chavoshi]], [[Peter McDonald (demographer)|Peter McDonald]] and [[Mohammad Jalal Abbasi-Shavazi]]}} {{Infobox book | | name = The Fertility Transition in Iran: Revolution and Reproduction | image = | caption = | authors = [[Meimanat Hosseini-Chavoshi]]
[[Peter McDonald (demographer)|Peter McDonald]]
[[Mohammad Jalal Abbasi-Shavazi]] | country = | language = English | subject = [[Demographics of Iran]] | publisher = [[Springer Publishing]] | pub_date = 2009 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = XXIV, 195 pp. | isbn = 978-90-481-3197-6 }} '''''The Fertility Transition in Iran: Revolution and Reproduction''''' is a 2009 book by [[Meimanat Hosseini-Chavoshi]], [[Peter McDonald (demographer)|Peter McDonald]] and [[Mohammad Jalal Abbasi-Shavazi]] in which the authors examine the [[fertility rate]] changes in the [[Islamic Republic of Iran]].{{cite journal |last1=McQuillan |first1=Kevin |title=Mohammad Jalal Abbasi-Shavazi, Peter McDonald, and Meimanat Hosseini-Chavoshi: The Fertility Transition in Iran: Revolution and Reproduction |journal=Studies in Family Planning |date=September 2011 |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=233–235 |doi=10.1111/j.1728-4465.2011.00285.x |url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1728-4465.2011.00285.x |accessdate=1 December 2018 |language=en |issn=0039-3665}}{{cite journal |last1=Erfani |first1=Amir |title=The Fertility Transition in Iran: Revolution and Reproduction |journal=Canadian Studies in Population |date=31 December 2011 |volume=38 |issue=1-2 |pages=203–205 |url=https://journals.library.ualberta.ca/csp/index.php/csp/article/view/16074/12879 |accessdate=1 December 2018 |issn=1927-629X}}{{cite journal |last1=Hull |first1=Terence H. |title=Review of The fertility transition in Iran: revolution and reproduction |journal=Journal of Population Research |date=2010 |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=243–245 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/41110977?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents |accessdate=1 December 2018}} The book was awarded [[Iran's Book of the Year Award]].{{cite web |title=Meimenat Hosseini-Chavoshi |url=http://demography.cass.anu.edu.au/news/profile-dr-meimenat-hosseini-chavoshi |website=ANU School of Demography |accessdate=1 December 2018 |language=en-AU |date=30 March 2012}}{{cite web |title=Springer book awarded prestigious prize in Iran |url=https://www.springer.com/about+springer/media/pressreleases?SGWID=0-11002-2-1085921-0 |website=springer.com |accessdate=1 December 2018 |language=en}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9789048131976 The Fertility Transition in Iran: Revolution and Reproduction] [[Category:2009 books]] [[Category:Springer Science+Business Media books]] [[Category:Demographics of Iran]] [[Category:Demography books]] {{Social-science-book-stub}}

page.title: Women's education in the United States

revision.comment: Remove 12 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
Higher education was designed for men in colonial America.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} Since the 1800s women's positions and opportunities in the educational sphere have increased. In 1982, women surpassed men in number of bachelor's degrees conferred in the United States, and more bachelor's degrees have been conferred on women each year since.<ref name="NCES">National Center for Education Statistics, [http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d12/tables/dt12_310.asp Digest of Education Statistics]. Retrieved 2015-02-21</ref><ref name="politifact">Molly O'Connor, [http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2014/jul/18/mitch-mcconnell/mitch-mcconnell-says-more-women-graduate-college-m/ "Mitch McConnell says more women graduate from college than men do"], ''Politifact,'' July 18, 2014. Retrieved 2015-02-21</ref> Since 2005, the majority of degrees in each category (including master's, and doctoral) have been conferred on women in the U.S.<ref name="politifact" />
==Statistics==
Since the early 1980s, women have surpassed men in terms of college enrollment rates.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Borzelleca |first1=Daniel |title=The Male-Female Ratio in College |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ccap/2012/02/16/the-male-female-ratio-in-college/#6712f43fa52d |website=Forbes |date=Feb 16, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=AP |first1=Associated Press |title=In a first, women surpass men in college degrees |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/in-a-first-women-surpass-men-in-college-degrees/ |website=CBS News |date=April 26, 2011}}</ref>
According to Ellen DuBoise and Lynn Dumenil, they estimate that the number of bachelor and doctorate degrees from 1950-1980 for women are:<ref>{{cite book |last1=DuBois |first1=Ellen Carol |last2=Dumenil |first2=Lynn |title=Through Women's Eyes : An American History with Documents |date=2009 |publisher=Bedford/St. Martin's |location=Boston |isbn=0312468873 |page=690 |edition= 2nd.}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" ! Year|| % of Bachelor Degrees || % of Doctorate Degrees |- | 1950 || 23.9% || 9.7% |- | 1960 || 35% || 10.5% |- | 1970 || 41.5% || 13.3% |- | 1980 || 49% || 30.3% |}
== History == ===Colonial===
In [[Colonial history of the United States|Colonial America]] elementary education was widespread in New England, but limited elsewhere. New England Puritans believed it was necessary to study the Bible, so boys and girls were taught to read at an early age. It was also required that each town pay for a primary school. About 10 percent enjoyed secondary schooling. Few girls attended formal schools, but most were able to get some education at home or at so-called "Dame schools" where women taught basic reading and writing skills in their own houses. By 1750, nearly 90% of New England's women and almost all of its men could read and write. There was no higher education for women.<ref>Lawrence Cremin, ''American Education: The Colonial Experience, 1607–1783'' (1972)</ref>
Tax-supported schooling for girls began as early as 1767 in New England. It was optional and some towns proved reluctant. Northampton, Massachusetts, for example, was a late adopter because it had many rich families who dominated the political and social structures and they did not want to pay taxes to aid poor families. Northampton assessed taxes on all households, rather than only on those with children, and used the funds to support a grammar school to prepare boys for college. Not until after 1800 did Northampton educate girls with public money. In contrast, the town of Sutton, Massachusetts, was diverse in terms of social leadership and religion at an early point in its history. Sutton paid for its schools by means of taxes on households with children only, thereby creating an active constituency in favor of universal education for both boys and girls.<ref>Kathryn Kish Sklar, "The Schooling of Girls and Changing Community Values in Massachusetts Towns, 1750–1820," ''History of Education Quarterly'' 1993 33(4): 511–542</ref> [[File:hollischoolhouse.jpg|thumb|Colonial schoolhouse in [[Hollis, New Hampshire]]]]
Historians point out that reading and writing were different skills in the colonial era. School taught both, but in places without schools reading was mainly taught to boys and also a few privileged girls. Men handled worldly affairs and needed to read and write. Girls only needed to read (especially religious materials). This educational disparity between reading and writing explains why the colonial women often could read, but could not write and could not sign their names—they used an "X".<ref>E. Jennifer Monaghan, "Literacy Instruction and Gender in Colonial New England," ''American Quarterly'' 1988 40(1): 18–41 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2713140 in JSTOR]</ref>
Across the South, there was very little public schooling. Most parents either home schooled their children using peripatetic tutors or sent them to small local private schools.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Lyon Gardiner |last=Tyler |title=Education in Colonial Virginia. Part II: Private Schools and Tutors |journal=William and Mary College Quarterly Historical Magazine |volume=6 |year=1897 |pages=1–6 }}</ref> A study of women's signatures in Georgia indicates a high degree of literacy in areas with schools.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Linda L. |last=Arthur |title=A New Look at Schooling and Literacy: The Colony of Georgia |journal=Georgia Historical Quarterly |year=2000 |volume=84 |issue=4 |pages=563–588 |doi= }}</ref> In South Carolina, scores of school projects were advertised in the ''South Carolina Gazette'' beginning in 1732.<ref>{{cite book |first=Sharon Braslaw |last=Sundue |title=Industrious in Their Stations: Young People at Work in Urban America, 1720–1810 |location=Charlottesville |publisher=University of Virginia Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-8139-2713-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ys0oAQAAIAAJ }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=James O'Neil |last=Spady |title=To Vie with One against Another: Race and Demand for Non-elite White Education in an Eighteenth-Century Colonial Society |journal=Early American Studies |year=2011 |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=649–676 |doi=10.1353/eam.2011.0028 }}</ref>
===20th century=== Coinciding with the beginnings of the [[First-wave feminism|first wave]] of [[feminism]] in the 20th century came the attempt by women to gain equal rights to education in the United States. Women's rights organizations focused on adjusting and increasing women's place in the public arena by arguing that the only fundamental differences between women and men were socially constructed ones, and thus women should be offered the same extensive and practical education that were offered to men. After long battles against gender oppression women finally obtained the right to be educated through several government acts/conventions, the opening of facilities willing to educate them, and the opportunity to continue into higher education.<ref name="Wood, J T. 2009">Wood, J T. (2009). Gendered Lives. Boston: Lyn Uhl.</ref>
===1930s=== Education was a controversial topic in the 1930s,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=37|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref>“ and sex-segregated school systems protected “the virtue of female high school students.” .”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=39|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref> Home economics and industrial education were new elements of the high school curriculum designed for unmistakably women's occupations.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=40|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref> These classes taught women practical skills such as sewing, cooking, and using the new domestic inventions of the era; unfortunately, this “formal training offered women little advantage in the struggle for stable work at a liveable wage.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=36|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref>
The 1930s also saw tremendous changes in women’s education at the college level. In 1900, there were 85,338 female college students in the United States and 5,237 earned their bachelor's degrees; by 1940, there were 600,953 female college students and 77,000 earned bachelor's degrees.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|pages=5–6}}</ref> This increase was partially explained by the “contemporary discourse that reinforced the need for higher education for women in their positions as wives, mothers, citizens, and professionals.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=8}}</ref>
Because the proper role for a white, middle class woman in 1930s American society was that of wife and mother,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=9}}</ref> arguments in favor of women's education emphasized concepts of eugenics and citizenship. Education showed women how to exercise their civic responsibilities, and it showed them the importance of the vote. Participation in student government trained women “early to become leaders later.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=17}}</ref> One study showed that in 1935, 62 percent of women college graduates voted compared to only 50 percent of women who did not attend college.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=18}}</ref>
The basic assumption in the 1930s was that women should marry. There was also the perception that college educated women were less likely to marry, either because they “waited too long” or because the college experience which broadened their minds deluded them into believing “marriage should be between equals.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=10}}</ref> Others argued college made women better wives and mothers<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=12}}</ref> because it “imparted practical skills.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=13}}</ref>
In addition, the 1930s marked great economic hardship in the United States with the start of the [[Great Depression]]. At this point in history, a college major was expected to be a practical one. As difficult financial times neared, needing to justify college expenses became very real for women and their families. A study in 1924 that surveyed nearly sixteen-hundred woman PhD recipients concluded that seventy percent required grants, scholarships, and fellowships in order to cover the expense associated with earning a higher degree. Despite the financial support, the majority of these women were required to save money for years before pursuing their degrees because the aid was never enough. Despite these disadvantages, the 1930s marked the peak of woman PhD earners. These degrees varied in fields and began to legitimize fields for women that were once off-limits.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Solomon|first1=Barabara|title=In the Company of Educated Women|date=1985|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven & London|page=136}}</ref>
The "self-support" that these women engaged in to help finance their education became a widely accepted necessity. Both men and women were forced to find ways of supporting their education at this period of time. To help lessen the financial burden faced by families trying to educate their children, the [[National Youth Administration]] was created by the [[United States Government]]. Between 1935 and 1943, the NYA spent nearly 93 million dollars providing financial assistance.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Solomon|first1=Barbara|title=In the Company of Educated Women|date=195|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven & London|page=148}}</ref> Despite the growing increasing opportunities for women in education, there was a constant need to justify the expense. As the number of college graduates increased, those who were displaced during the [[Great Depression]] had to compete with a younger and more-educated group of people.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Horowitz|first1=Helen|title=Alma Mater: Design and Experience in the Women's Colleges from Their Nineteenth-Century Beginnings to the 1930's|date=1984|publisher=University of Massachusetts Press|location=Amherst, MA|page=115}}</ref>
The 1930s also marked the 10th anniversary of [[Women's suffrage in the United States]]. Despite earning the right to vote, women were still largely refused any role in positions of political power that allow them to make political change for their gender.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Deckard|first1=Barbara|title=The Women's Movement: Political, Socioeconomic. and Psychological Issues|date=1983|publisher=Harper & Row|location=New York|page=228|edition= Third}}</ref> Despite growing numbers of women graduates, many were denied positions that they were qualified for in favor of men. This struggle sparked new examples of [[political activism]] and increased support for an [[Equal Rights Amendment]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McGowan|first1=Josephine|title=A Decade of Women's Rights|journal=Commonwealth|date=February 11, 1931|page=403}}</ref>
====Areas of study==== [[File:Shimer College Home Economics cooking 1942.jpg|thumb|Home economics students at [[Shimer College]] in 1942.]] Teaching and nursing were the top two fields for women throughout the 1930s,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=22}}</ref> but [[home economics]] also experienced a great surge in popularity during the Depression.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=23}}</ref> Home economics brought a scientific language to the traditional women’s sphere of the home and raised “homemaking to the status of a respectable--though definitely female--occupation.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=22|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref> Social work, child development, and nursery school educational programs were also popular.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=23|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref>
In addition to this strong vocational orientation in American education during the opening decades of the twentieth century,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rury|first=John|title=Vocationalism for Home and Work: Women's Education in the United States, 1880–1930|journal=History of Education Quarterly|date=Spring 1984|volume=24|issue=1|page=21|doi=10.2307/367991}}</ref> women began to make slow inroads into traditionally male dominated areas of education such as business, science, medicine, architecture, engineering, and law.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|pages=21–22}}</ref> Women were also able to gain positions of responsibility within the federal government because of the watershed events of the New Deal.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nash|first=Margaret|author2=Romero, Lisa|title="Citizenship for the College Girl": Challenges and Opportunities in Higher Education for Women in the United States in the 1930s|journal=Teachers College Record|year=2012|volume=114|issue=2|page=7}}</ref>
=== Women's colleges === {{main|Women's colleges in the United States}}
Prior to the [[American Civil War]] few colleges admitted women. Founded in 1772 as a primary school, [[Salem College]] is the oldest female educational establishment.
Some were founded as co-educational institutions; [[Oberlin College]], founded in 1833, was the first college to accept women and [[African American]]s as students.<ref>{{cite book|author=Faustine Childress Jones-Wilson|title=Encyclopedia of African-American Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ni2qhq1n1d4C&pg=PA339|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood|pages=339–40}}</ref>
Other early coeducational schools included Hillsdale College founded as Michigan Central College in Spring Arbor, Michigan in 1844,<ref>{{cite web|title = About/History - Hillsdale College|url = http://www.hillsdale.edu/about/history|website = www.hillsdale.edu|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> and Antioch College founded by noted educator Horace Mann in 1852 in Yellow Springs, Ohio.<ref>{{cite web|title = Mission & History {{!}} Antioch College|url = http://www.antiochcollege.org/about/mission_and_history.html|website = www.antiochcollege.org|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> Hollins University, founded as Valley Union Seminary in Roanoke, Virginia, in 1842 as a co-educational institution but became all-female in 1952;<ref>{{cite web|title = History & Mission {{!}} Hollins University|url = https://www.hollins.edu/who-we-are/history/|website = Hollins|access-date = 2016-02-07|language = en-US}}</ref>
A number of colleges were founded before the Civil War with all-female student bodies, including (among others, in addition to Salem): Mount Holyoke College of South Hadley, Massachusetts, founded in 1837 by [[Mary Lyon]] as Mount Holyoke Female Seminary;<ref>{{cite web|title = History|url = https://www.mtholyoke.edu/about/history|website = Mount Holyoke College|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> Wesleyan College of Macon, Georgia, founded in 1839 as Georgia Female College, which claims to be "the first college in the world chartered to grant degrees to women";<ref>{{cite web|title = About Wesleyan|url = http://www.wesleyancollege.edu/about/index.cfm|website = www.wesleyancollege.edu|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> Queens College (now Queens University) of Charlotte, North Carolina, founded in 1857 as Charlotte Female Institute;<ref>{{cite web|title = History of Queens {{!}} Queens University of Charlotte|url = http://www.queens.edu/About-Queens/Get-to-Know-Queens/History-of-Queens.html|website = www.queens.edu|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> Averett College (now Averett University) of Danville, Virginia, founded in 1859 as Union women's College;<ref>{{cite web|title = History|url = http://www.averett.edu/about-us/office-of-the-president/history/|website = www.averett.edu|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> and Vassar College, founded in Poughkeepsie, New York in 1861.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Maryann Bruno|author2=Elizabeth A. Daniels|title=Vassar College|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8bEfDUaq8HEC&pg=PA7|year=2001|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|page=7}}</ref>
With the start of the war many males were in uniform so more opportunities arose for women to fill the empty space in schools and the universities became more willing to admit the women.<ref>[http://www.ed.gov/offices/OERI/PLLI/webreprt.html Women's Colleges in the United States: History, Issues, and Challenges.] Irene Harwarth & Mindi Maline. 5 Apr. 2009. U.S. Department of Education, Washington, D.C.. 5 Apr. 2009.</ref> Slowly more educational institutions opened their doors to women; today, there are 60 women's colleges in the United States offering educational programs that parallel co-educational universities both in subject matter and in quality.
=== Government action=== In 1848 the [[Seneca Falls Convention]] was held in New York to gain support for education and suffrage but it had little immediate impact. This convention is significant because it created a foundation for efforts toward equal education for women, even though it was not actually achieved until much later.<ref name="Wood, J T. 2009" />
The [[Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act]] of 1862 founded universities to educate both men and women in practical fields of study, though women's courses were still centered around home economics. By 1870 30% of colleges were co-educational, later in the 1930s women-only colleges were established that expanded opportunities for courses of study to include more intellectual development as opposed to domestic instruction.<ref name="Wood, J T. 2009" />
In July 1975 “[[Title IX]] regulations became effective as law” (Margaret Fund of NWLC, 2012). The law provided one year for compliance to elementary schools and three years for compliance to high schools and post secondary institutions. Through the 1970s the law’s enactment, opposition towards the legislation, and initial compliance for the law were the focus. According to the Margaret Fund (2012), in 1982 a court case was won upholding the nondiscriminatory acts in employment, the case title is as follows, 1982 North Haven Bd. of Ed. v. Bell, 456 U.S. 512 (1982). In 1984, the case Grove City v. Bell, 465 U.S. 555 (1984) a, “U.S. Supreme Court decision held that federal spending clause statutes only apply to those programs or activities that receive direct federal financial assistance, effectively ending Title IX applicability to athletics” (Margaret Fund of NWLC). This decision is later remedied in the late 80’s by the Civil Rights Restoration Act of 1987. In 1988, this act was passed by Congress and reversed the damage from the Grove City v. Bell decision. The Margaret Fund (2012) states, “It over-rode the Grove City v. Bell decision by expanding the definition of program or activity that receives Federal financial assistance” (Margaret Fund of NWLC, para.5). During the 1990s three significant changes or continuations to the law were made in the course of the decade. First, a Supreme Court decision allowed an individual to sue for monetary retributions by citing the Title IX Act. Second, the disclosure act in 1994 stated that all institutions under Title IX were to report publicly on their operations, with an effective implementation date set for 1996. Third, the ORC distributed requirements to institutions and schools which are explained and outlined more clearly the regulations for Title IX. The significant events in the 2000s allow schools to use e-mail surveys, and due to a Supreme Court case in 2009, lawsuits on the basis of sexual discrimination under Title IX can be brought by parents.
== Timeline == [[File:Anandibai Joshee, Kei Okami, and Tabat M. Islambooly.jpg|thumb|[[Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania]] in 1886: [[Anandibai Joshee]] from India (left) with [[Kei Okami]] from Japan (center) and [[Sabat Islambooly]] from Syria (right). All three completed their medical studies and each of them was the first woman from their respective countries to obtain a degree in Western medicine.]] {{See also|Women's colleges in the Southern United States#Historically black colleges|l1=Timeline of historically black women's colleges|Timeline of women's education|Timeline of women's colleges in the United States|Women's colleges in the United States}}
'''1727:''' Founded in 1727 by [[Ursulines|the Sisters of the Order of Saint Ursula]], [[Ursuline Academy (New Orleans)|Ursuline Academy, New Orleans]], enjoys the distinction of being both the oldest continuously operating school for girls and the oldest Catholic school in the United States.
'''1742:''' Moravians in Pennsylvania established the first all-girls boarding school in America, the [[Bethlehem Female Seminary]] to serve the Moravian community in and near Bethlehem. In 1863 it became a college. In 1913 it became [[Moravian Seminary and College for Women]]. Historians accept Moravian as the oldest—though not continuously operational because of its current co-ed status—specifically female institute of higher learning in the United States.<ref>Mabel Haller, "Moravian Influence on Higher Education in Colonial America." ''Pennsylvania History'' 25#3 (1958): 205-222</ref>
'''1783:''' [[Washington College]] in [[Chestertown, Maryland|Chestertown]], Maryland, appointed the first women instructors at any American college. Elizabeth Callister Peale and Sarah Callister taught painting and drawing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washcoll.edu/about/buildings/kohl-gallery/history.php |title=Kohl Gallery: History |publisher=Washington College |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
'''1803:''' Bradford Academy in Bradford, Massachusetts was the first higher educational institution to admit women in Massachusetts. It was founded as a co-educational institution, but became exclusively for women in 1837.
'''1826:''' The first American public high schools for girls were opened in New York and Boston.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jFY3CxmHk4cC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=girl+geometry+1829&source=bl&ots=gHk5ySOaVc&sig=5IjxVTtJVG4kfU6d699H0D9PXs8&hl=en&ei=AOqYTcfjEeyx0QH5vpWCDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=girl%20geometry%201829&f=false |title=Chronology of women's history |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1829:''' The first public examination of an American girl in geometry was held.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4kEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&|title=History of Woman Suffrage: 1848–1861, Volume 1|page= 36|editor1=Elizabeth Cady Stanton |editor2=Susan B. Anthony |editor3=Matilda Joslyn Gage |editor4=Ida Husted Harper |date=1889 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1831:''' As a private institution in 1831, [[Mississippi College]] became the first coeducational college in the United States to grant a degree to a woman. In December 1831 it granted degrees to two women, Alice Robinson and Catherine Hall.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nNnVX4gQdD0C&pg=PA23 |page=23 |title=Looking Back Mississippi: Towns and Places |last=Cooper |first=Forrest Lamar |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year=2011 |isbn=9781617031489}}</ref>
'''1837:''' Bradford Academy in Bradford, Massachusetts, due to declining enrollment, became a single-sexed institution for the education of women exclusively.
1837 Mount Holyoke College was founded by Mary Lyon.
'''1849:''' [[Elizabeth Blackwell]], born in England, became the first woman to earn a medical degree from an American college, Geneva Medical College in New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biography_35.html |title=Changing the Face of Medicine | Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell |publisher=Nlm.nih.gov |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1850:''' [[Lucy Sessions]] earned a literary degree from Oberlin College, becoming the first African American woman in the United States to receive a college degree.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/africanamerican/25.html |title=Claiming Their Citizenship: African American Women From 1624–2009 |publisher=Nwhm.org |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1851:''' The Adelphean Society, now called [[Alpha Delta Pi]] Women's Fraternity, was founded at Wesleyan Female College in Macon, Georgia and became the first secret society for women.
'''1855:''' The [[University of Iowa]] becomes the first coeducational [[Public university|public]] or state university in the United States.<ref name=Roch>{{Citation | first = A.J. | last = May | title = University of Rochester History | url = http://www.lib.rochester.edu/index.cfm?PAGE=2319 }}</ref>
'''1858:''' [[Mary Fellows]] became the first woman west of the Mississippi River to receive a baccalaureate degree.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/education/Timeline.htm |title=NWHM Exhibit: The History of Women and Education |publisher=Nwhm.org |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1862:''' [[Mary Jane Patterson]] became the first African-American woman to earn a BA in 1862. She earned her degree from Oberlin College.<ref>Jessie Carney Smith, "Mary Jane Patterson." ''Notable Black Women'' (Gale Research, 1992).</ref>
'''1864:''' [[Rebecca Crumpler]] became the first African-American woman to graduate from a U.S. college with a medical degree and the first and only African-American woman to obtain the Doctress of Medicine degree from New England Female Medical College in Boston, MA.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1866:''' [[Lucy Hobbs Taylor]] became the first American woman to earn a dental degree, which she earned from the Ohio College of Dental Surgery.<ref name="catalyst1">{{cite web|url=http://www.catalyst.org/publication/211/firsts-for-us-women |title=Firsts for U.S. Women |publisher=Catalyst |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~thorsdag/LucyHobbsTaylor.html |title=Lucy Hobbs Taylor, First Female Dentist |publisher=Home.comcast.net |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1866:''' [[Sarah Jane Woodson Early]] became the first African-American woman to serve as a professor. Xenia, Ohio’s Wilberforce University hired her to teach Latin and English in 1866.<ref>Ellen Lawson and Marlene Merrill, ''The Three Sarahs: Documents of Antebellum Black College Women'' (Edwin Mellen Press, 1984).</ref>
'''1869:''' [[Fanny Jackson Coppin]] was named principal of the Institute for Colored Youth in Philadelphia, becoming the first African-American woman to head an institution for higher learning in the United States.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1870:''' [[Ada Kepley]] became the first American woman to earn a law degree, from Northwestern School of Law.<ref>[http://www.lawcrossing.com/article/3887/Northwestern-University-School-of-Law-Chicago-Illinois/] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720234225/http://www.lawcrossing.com/article/3887/Northwestern-University-School-of-Law-Chicago-Illinois/ |date=July 20, 2011 }}</ref>
'''1870:''' [[Ellen Swallow Richards]] became the first American woman to earn a degree in chemistry, which she earned from [[Vassar College]] in 1870.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=cVtFJ5tvINsC&pg=PA387&lpg=PA387&dq=%22first+woman+to+earn+a+degree+in+chemistry%22&source=bl&ots=Y_P1-rvlze&sig=pfbf2WxVAO6HAxE5ff9nMr-gc_o&hl=en&sa=X&ei=arQXU5uGMIXq0AGY-oGYDw&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22first%20woman%20to%20earn%20a%20degree%20in%20chemistry%22&f=false Encyclopedia of Women and American Politics - Lynne E. Ford - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
'''1871:''' [[Frances Elizabeth Willard]] became the first female college president in the United States, as president of Evanston College for Ladies in Illinois.<ref name="catalyst1"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nFt6csjzc48C&pg=PA468&lpg=PA468&dq=frances+elizabeth+willard+%22first+female+college+president%22&source=bl&ots=GwLPliiwJ7&sig=_yrmAHe8bmLxWEIOK6uV1h0Pbmo&hl=en&ei=bRo7TbPMHou_gQfploHbCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=frances%20elizabeth%20willard%20%22first%20female%20college%20president%22&f=false |title=Historical dictionary of women's ... |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1871:''' [[Harriette Cooke]] became the first woman college professor in the United States appointed full professor with a salary equal to her male peers.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
'''1871:''' Japanese women are allowed to study in the USA (though not yet in Japan itself).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_OOeA2H5aKIC&pg=PA100|title=The History of Modern Japanese Education: Constructing the National School System 1872–1890|last=Duke|first=Benjamin|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-4403-8|year=2009}}</ref>
'''1873:''' [[Linda Richards]] became the first American woman to earn a degree in nursing.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R0eSPstPtMcC&pg=PA271&lpg=PA271&dq=%22first+american+woman+to+receive+a+degree+in+%22&source=bl&ots=vd6e0zDZ0g&sig=WyH-JpXdTgoG0PZVqBYgV1a_Fbc&hl=en&ei=-YYjTamPMcKblgfB_ICrDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22first%20american%20woman%20to%20receive%20a%20degree%20in%20%22&f=false |title=More than Title nine |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1877:''' [[Helen Magill White]] became the first American woman to earn a Ph.D., which she earned at Boston University in the subject of Greek.<ref name="catalyst1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/facts/5/238723/Helen-Magill-White-as-discussed-in-Boston-University-university-Boston-Massachusetts-United-States |title=Facts about Helen Magill White: Boston University, as discussed in Boston University (university, Boston, Massachusetts, United States): - Britannica Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Britannica.com |date=1944-10-28 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rmc.library.cornell.edu/ead/htmldocs/RMM04107.html |title=Guide to the Helen Magill White Papers, 1865–1938 |publisher=Rmc.library.cornell.edu |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1878:''' [[Mary L. Page]] became the first American woman to earn a degree in architecture, which she earned from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jh7ecV24_uAC&pg=PA372&dq=mary+l+page+architect&hl=en&ei=5rneTPmEAsXflgeAlondAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6wEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Almanac of Architecture & Design 2006 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EIhMAAAAYAAJ&q=%22first+american+woman+%22+mary+l+page&dq=%22first+american+woman+%22+mary+l+page&hl=en&ei=pIgjTdSiNoSClAfb5aDWDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAg |title=Journal of the American Institute of ... |date=2010-03-03 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1879:''' [[Mary Eliza Mahoney]] became the first African-American in the U.S. to earn a diploma in nursing, which she earned from the School of Nursing, New England Hospital for Woman and Children in Boston.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1886:''' [[Winifred Edgerton Merrill]] became the first American woman to earn a PhD in mathematics, which she earned from Columbia University.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kelly |first=Susan E. |last2=Rozner |first2=Sarah A. |url=http://www.ams.org/notices/201204/rtx120400504p.pdf |title=Winifred Edgerton Merrill: "She Opened the Door" |publisher=Notices of the AMS |date=April 2012 |format=PDF |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
'''1889:''' [[Maria Louise Baldwin]] became the first African-American female principal in Massachusetts and the Northeast, supervising white faculty and a predominantly white student body at the Agassiz Grammar School in Cambridge.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1889:''' [[Susan La Flesche Picotte]] became the first Native American woman to earn a medical degree, which she earned from [[Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biography_253.html |title=Dr. Susan La Flesche Picotte |publisher=National Library of Medicine |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.drexelmed.edu/timeline.php |title=History of Women Physicians - Timeline |publisher=Drexel University, College of Medicine |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
'''1890:''' [[Ida Gray]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Doctor of Dental Surgery degree, which she earned from the University of Michigan.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourweekly.com/los-angeles/black-history-fact-week-ida-gray-nelson-rollins |title=Black History Fact of the Week: Ida Gray Nelson Rollins | Our Weekly - African American News | Black News | Black Entertainment | Black America |publisher=Our Weekly |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1892:''' [[Laura Eisenhuth]] became the first woman elected to state office as Superintendent of Public Instruction.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
'''1894:''' [[Margaret Floy Washburn]] became the first woman to be officially awarded the PhD degree in psychology, which she earned at Cornell University under [[Edward Titchener|E. B. Titchener]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feministvoices.com/past-timeline/ |title=Timeline - Psychology's Feminist Voices |publisher=Feministvoices.com |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''Late 1800s, exact date unknown:''' [[Anandibai Joshi]] from India, [[Keiko Okami]] from Japan, and [[Sabat Islambouli]] from Syria became the first women from their respective countries (and in Joshi's case the first Hindu woman) to get a degree in western medicine, which they each got from the Women’s Medical College of Pennsylvania (WMCP), where they were all students in 1885.<ref>[http://pri.org/stories/2013-07-12/historical-photos-depict-women-medical-pioneers Historical Photos Depict Women Medical Pioneers | Public Radio International<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Women's Book of World Records and Achievements|author=Eron, Carol<!-- for the chapter -->|editor=O'Neill, Lois Decker|publisher=Anchor Press|year=1979|page=204|chapter=Women in Medicine and Health Care|isbn=0-385-12733-2|quote=First Hindu Woman Doctor}}</ref>
'''1900:''' [[Otelia Cromwell]] became the first African-American woman to graduate from [[Smith College]] in Northampton, Massachusetts.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1903:''' [[Mignon Nicholson]] became the first woman in North America to earn a veterinary degree, which she earned from [[McKillip Veterinary College]] in Chicago, Illinois.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vet.k-state.edu/centennial/bytes.htm |title=The Centennial: Did You Know? |publisher=KSU College of Veterinary Medicine |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:K2Xs146pNa4J:www.womenveterinarians.org/uploadFiles/H1_02.pdf+mckillip+veterinary+college&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgBClhf8kRiIYdUkRJcMQvGnGP4Ssovy54OyuLSoz7uJV5yfFBTjFQuJWDeOA5anJQK0DqCNUYmL8m6V1txlA4nafDfeIIrVkRySeKianlUvUGUnhvnt9wWE1ZO-1vic5xX8bnQ&sig=AHIEtbRBxIOMAFK0rv6-vfABv4Lf2lRuhw |title=Early Women Veterinarians in the Western Hemisphere |publisher=McKillip Veterinary College |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
'''1904:''' [[Helen Keller]] graduated from Radcliffe, becoming the first [[deafblind]] person to earn a Bachelor of Arts degree.
'''1905:''' [[Nora Stanton Blatch Barney]], born in England, became the first woman to earn a degree in any type of engineering in the United States, which she earned from Cornell University. It was a degree in civil engineering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engineeringdegree.net/resources/women-in-engineering/ |title=Women in Engineering |publisher=Engineering Degree |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1908:''' [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] Sorority, the first African-American Greek letter organization for woman, was founded at Howard University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1909:''' [[Ella Flagg Young]] became the first female superintendent of a large city school system.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
'''1915:''' [[Lillian Gilbreth]] earned a PhD in [[industrial psychology]] from Brown University, which was the first degree ever granted in industrial psychology. Her dissertation was titled "Some Aspects of Eliminating Waste in Teaching".
'''1917:''' [[Sigma Delta Tau]] Sorority, a Jewish women's Greek letter organization was founded at [[Cornell University]] in response to antisemitism.
'''1921:''' [[Sadie Tanner Mossell Alexander|Sadie Tanner Mossell]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in the U.S. when she earned a Ph.D. in Economics from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]<ref name="Boston1997">{{cite book|last=Malveaux|first=Julianne|editor=Thomas D. Boston|title=A Different Vision: Africa American Economic Thought|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WMwRwp9QImAC&pg=PA123|accessdate=4 June 2013|volume=1|year=1997|publisher=Routledge Chapman & Hall|isbn=978-0-415-12715-8|pages=123–|chapter=Missed Opportunity: Sadie Teller Mossell Alexander and the Economics Profession}}</ref>
'''1922:''' [[Sigma Gamma Rho]] Sorority was founded. It was the fourth African-American Greek letter organization for women, and the first African-American sorority established on a predominantly white campus, Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1922:''' [[Lorna Myrtle Hodgkinson]] became the first woman to earn a Ph.D. from Harvard, which she earned in education.<ref>{{cite web|last=Henderson |first=Margaret |url=http://m.northernstar.com.au/news/northern-rivers-medical-pioneer/2491828/ |title=First woman to receive doctorate at Harvard was from Lennox | Northern Star |publisher=M.northernstar.com.au |date=2014-12-22 |accessdate=2016-05-27}}</ref>
'''1923:''' [[Virginia Proctor Powell Florence]] became the first African-American woman to earn a degree in library science. She earned the degree in 1923 from the Carnegie Library School, which later became part of the University of Pittsburgh.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Celeste Kimbrough |url=http://www.news.pitt.edu/news/university-pittsburgh-honor-first-african-american-librarian-plaque-dedication-ceremony-april-2 |title=University of Pittsburgh to Honor First African American Librarian In Plaque Dedication Ceremony April 2 | University of Pittsburgh News |publisher=News.pitt.edu |date=2004-03-18 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1925:''' [[Zora Neale Hurston]] became the first African-American woman to be admitted to Barnard college.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
'''1926:''' Dr. [[May Edward Chinn]] became the first African-American woman to graduate from the University and Bellevue Hospital Medical College.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1929:''' [[Jenny Rosenthal Bramley]], born in Moscow, became the first woman to earn a Ph.D. in physics in the United States, which she earned from New York University.<ref>[http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Jenny_Rosenthal_Bramley Jenny Rosenthal Bramley - GHN: IEEE Global History Network<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
'''1931:''' [[Jane Matilda Bolin]] was the first African-American woman to graduate from Yale Law School.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1932:''' [[Dorothy B. Porter]] became the first African-American woman to earn an advanced degree in library science (MLS) from Columbia University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1933:''' [[Inez Beverly Prosser]] became the first African-American woman to earn a PhD in psychology, which she earned from the [[University of Cincinnati]].
'''1934:''' [[Ruth Winifred Howard]] became the second African-American woman in the United States to receive a Ph.D. in psychology, which she earned from the University of Minnesota.
'''1935:''' [[Jesse Jarue Mark]] became the first African American woman to earn a Ph.D. in botany, which she earned at Iowa State University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1936:''' [[Flemmie Kittrell]] became the first African American woman to earn a Ph.D. in nutrition, which she earned at Cornell University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1937:''' [[Anna Johnson Julian]] became the first African-American woman to receive a Ph.D. in sociology from the University of Pennsylvania.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1940:''' [[Roger Arliner Young]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in zoology, which she earned from the University of Pennsylvania.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Marion Thompson Wright became the first African-American woman in the United States to earn a Ph.D. in History, which she earned at Columbia University.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.blackpast.org/aah/wright-marion-thompson-1902-1962|title=Wright, Marion Thompson (1902–1962) {{!}} The Black Past: Remembered and Reclaimed|website=www.blackpast.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
'''1941:''' [[Ruth Lloyd]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in anatomy, which she earned from Western Reserve University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1941:''' [[Merze Tate]] became the first African American woman to earn a Ph.D. in government and international relations from Harvard University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1942:''' [[Margurite Thomas]] became the first African American woman to earn a Ph.D. in geology, which she earned from Catholic University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1943:''' [[Euphemia Haynes]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in Mathematics, which she earned from Catholic University.<ref name="buffalo1">{{cite web|url=http://www.math.buffalo.edu/mad/wohist.html |title=History of Black Women in the Mathematical Sciences |publisher=Math.buffalo.edu |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1945:''' [[Harvard Medical School]] admitted women for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:uQQmyQmkJ8AJ:www.ama-assn.org/ama1/pub/upload/mm/19/wimtimeline.pdf+%22+harvard+medical+school+first+admits+women%22&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESi9Ev1hsGhe1RbX5o_cdrqG4_r7FIy0gVAPY1SVX5aGnyUV18GvX4Q2FexSZT1prRzCsdzKvI1u-hUqs5jnK_omf5mYsJDmbq5RDDCi7o7-yChw1AogL7gyBT_ec7lGVFuH7ot4&sig=AHIEtbSvvu-9sit0bSIBlHbR5UBL6hpJLQ |title=Powered by Google Docs |publisher=Docs.google.com |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1947:''' [[Marie Maynard Daly]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in chemistry, which she earned from Columbia University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/marie-m-daly-604034 |title=Marie M. Daly Biography - Facts, Birthday, Life Story |publisher=Biography.com |date=1921-04-16 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1962:''' [[Martha Bernal]], who was born in Texas, became the first Latina to earn a PhD in psychology, which she earned in clinical psychology from Indiana University Bloomington.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apadivisions.org/division-35/about/heritage/martha-bernal-biography.aspx |title=Biography of Martha Bernal |publisher=Apadivisions.org |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feministvoices.com/presence-timeline/ |title=Timeline - Psychology's Feminist Voices |publisher=Feministvoices.com |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1963:''' [[Grace Alele-Williams]] became the first Nigerian woman to earn any doctorate when she earned her Ph.D. in Mathematics Education from the University of Chicago.<ref name="buffalo1"/>
'''1965:''' [[Sister Mary Kenneth Keller]] (1914? - 1985) became the first American woman to earn a PhD in Computer Science, which she earned at the University of Wisconsin–Madison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computinghistorymuseum.org/teaching/papers/research/steel.pdf|title=Women in Computing - Computing History Museum|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.wisc.edu/includes/textfiles/phds.65-70.txt|title=UW-Madison Computer Science Ph.D.s Awarded, May 1965 - August 1970|accessdate=2010-11-08}} PhDs granted at UW-Madison Computer Sciences Department.</ref> Her thesis was titled "Inductive Inference on Computer Generated Patterns."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://research.cs.wisc.edu/includes/textfiles/phds.65-70.txt |title=UW-Madison Computer Science Ph.D.s Awarded, May 1965 - August 1970 |publisher=Wisc.edu |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref>
'''1972:''' [[Title IX]] was passed, making discrimination against any person based on their sex in any federally funded educational program(s) in America illegal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bailiwick.lib.uiowa.edu/ge/aboutRE.html |title=About Title IX |publisher=Bailiwick.lib.uiowa.edu |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1972:''' [[Willie Hobbs Moore]] became the first African-American woman to earn a Ph.D. in Physics, which she earned from the University of Michigan.<ref name="buffalo1"/>
'''1975:''' In 1975, [[Lorene Rogers]] became the first woman named president of a major research university, The University of Texas.
'''1975:''' On July 1, 1975, [[Jeanne Sinkford]] became the first female dean of a dental school when she was appointed the dean of [[Howard University]], School of Dentistry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cda.org/page/Library/cda_member/pubs/journal/jour0602/hyson.html |title=June 2002 CDA Journal - Feature Article, Copyright 2002 Journal of the California Dental Association |publisher=Cda.org |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1976:''' U.S. service academies (US Military Academy, US Naval Academy, US Air Force Academy and the US Coast Guard Academy) first admitted women in 1976.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chnm.gmu.edu/courses/rr/s01/cw/students/leeann/historyandcollections/history/spotlight/lrnmreacademies.htm |title=Women in the US Military - Women Enter the Military Academies |publisher=Chnm.gmu.edu |date=1975-10-07 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1977:''' The [[American Association of Dental Schools]] (founded in 1923 and renamed the [[American Dental Education Association]] in 2000) had Nancy Goorey as its first female president in 1977.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://selaminternational.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=52 |title=selaminternational.org |publisher=selaminternational.org |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1977-1978''': For the first time, more associate degrees are conferred on women than men in the United States. More associate degrees have been conferred on women every year since.<ref name="NCES" />
'''1979:''' [[Christine Economides]] became the first American woman to earn a PhD in petroleum engineering, which she earned from Stanford University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://advance.tamu.edu/accomplished_individual.php?faculty=194 |title=ADVANCE Center for Women Faculty |publisher=Advance.tamu.edu |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
'''1979:''' [[Jenny Patrick]] became the first African-American woman in the United States to earn a Ph.D. in chemical engineering, which she earned from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1980:''' Women and men were enrolled in American colleges in equal numbers for the first time.<ref name="cwrl.utexas.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.cwrl.utexas.edu/~ulrich/femhist/education.shtml |title=Horany, E. (2002). Women's Issues Then & Now. Retrieved Mar. 2, 2009, from University of Texas, Texas, website |publisher=Cwrl.utexas.edu |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
'''1981-1982''': For the first time, more bachelor's degrees are conferred on women than men in the United States. More bachelor's degrees have been conferred on women every year since.<ref name="NCES" /><ref name="politifact" /> [[File:U.S. degrees conferred per year.png|thumb|380px|Degrees conferred in United States since 1970 by year, degree type, and gender. Dashed lines are projected. Since 1982 more bachelor's degrees have been conferred on women.<ref name="NCES" />]]
'''1982:''' ''[[Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan]]'', [[Case citation|458 U.S. 718]] (1982) was a case decided 5-4 by the [[Supreme Court of the United States]]. The court held that the [[Single-sex education|single-sex admissions]] policy of the [[Mississippi University for Women]] violated the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0458_0718_ZO.html |title=Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan |publisher=Law.cornell.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>
'''1982:''' [[Judith Hauptman]] earned her PhD in Talmudic studies from the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, thus making her the first woman to earn a PhD in [[Talmud]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ohel Ayalah - Who We Are|url=http://www.ohelayalah.org/about/bios|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref><ref name=jewish-singles>{{cite web|title=abba & rabbi: an evening with sara hurwitz & judith hauptman|url=http://www.jewishtodo.com/EventDetails.aspx?ID=332|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://www.jtsa.edu/Academics/Faculty_Profiles/Judith_Hauptman_Bio.xml?ID_NUM=100233 The Jewish Theological Seminary - Judith Hauptman<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
'''1983:''' [[Christine Darden]] became the first African-American woman in the U.S. to earn a Ph.D. degree in mechanical engineering, which she earned from George Washington University.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1984:''' The U.S. Supreme Court's 1984 ruling ''[[Grove City College v. Bell]]''<ref name="oyez">[http://oyez.org/cases/1980-1989/1983/1983_82_792 "The Oyez Project, Grove City College v. Bell"] , 465 U.S. 555 (1984)</ref> held that Title IX applied only to those programs receiving direct federal aid.<ref name="EB">[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/597287/Title-IX "Title IX."] ''Encyclopædia Britannica''. 2009. Encyclopædia Britannica Online. 19 Nov. 2009</ref> The case reached the Supreme Court when [[Grove City College]] disagreed with the Department of Education's assertion that it was required to comply with Title IX. Grove City College was not a federally funded institution; however, they did accept students who were receiving [[Basic Educational Opportunity Grant]]s through a Department of Education program.<ref name="oyez"/> The Department of Education's stance was that, because some of its students were receiving federal grants, the school was receiving federal assistance and Title IX applied to it. The Court decided that since Grove City College was only receiving federal funding through the grant program, only that program had to be in compliance. The ruling was a major victory for those opposed to Title IX, as it made many institutions' sports programs outside of the rule of Title IX and, thus, reduced the scope of Title IX.<ref name="Suggs">Suggs, Welsh. ''A Place on the Team.'' Princeton, NJ.: Princeton University Press, 2005.</ref>
'''1986-1987''': For the first time, more master's degrees are conferred on women than men in the United States. More master's degrees have been conferred on women every year since.<ref name="NCES" />
'''1987:''' [[Johnnetta Cole]] became the first African-American president of [[Spelman College]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''1988:''' The Civil Rights Restoration Act was passed in 1988 which extended Title IX coverage to all programs of any educational institution that receives any federal assistance, both direct and indirect.<ref name="now">[http://www.now.org/issues/title_ix/history.html "Legislative History of Title IX"] National Organization for Women. June 27, 2007.</ref>
'''1994:''' [[Judith Rodin]] became the first permanent female president of an Ivy League University (specifically, the [[University of Pennsylvania]].) <ref>[http://www.upenn.edu/president/about-presidency/history-presidency#rodin History of the Presidency : Office of the President : University of Pennsylvania<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
'''1994:''' In 1994, the Equity in Athletics Disclosure Act, sponsored by congresswoman [[Cardiss Collins]], required federally assisted higher education institutions to disclose information on roster sizes for men's and women's teams, as well as budgets for recruiting, scholarships, coaches' salaries, and other expenses, annually.<ref name="cases">[http://bailiwick.lib.uiowa.edu/ge/historyRE.html "Landmark Title IX Cases in History"] Gender Equity in Sport. February 23, 2006.</ref>
'''1996:''' ''[[United States v. Virginia]]'', {{ussc|518|515|1996}}, was a [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark case]] in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] struck down the [[Virginia Military Institute]] (VMI)'s long-standing [[Men's college|male-only admission policy]] in a 7-1 decision. (Justice [[Clarence Thomas]], whose son was enrolled at VMI at the time, [[recusal|recused]] himself.)
'''2001:''' [[Ruth Simmons]] became the eighteenth president of Brown University, which made her the first African-American woman to lead an Ivy League institution.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
'''2004–2005:''' For the first time, more doctoral degrees degrees are conferred on women than men in the United States women. More doctoral degrees have been conferred on women every year since.<ref name="NCES" /><ref>{{cite web|last=Jaschik |first=Scott |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2010-09-15-womenphd14_st_N.htm |title=For first time, more women than men earn PhD |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date=2010-09-14 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref> As of 2011, among adults 25 and older, 10.6 million U.S. women have master's degrees or higher, compared to 10.5 million men. Measured by shares, about 10.2 percent of women have advanced degrees compared to 10.9 percent of men—a gap steadily narrowing in recent years. Women still trail men in professional subcategories such as business, science and engineering, but when it comes to finishing college, roughly 20.1 million women have bachelor's degrees, compared to nearly 18.7 million men—a gap of more than 1.4 million that has remained steady in recent years.<ref name="yahoo1">[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110426/ap_on_re_us/us_census_educated_women ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110504043737/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110426/ap_on_re_us/us_census_educated_women |date=May 4, 2011 }}</ref>
'''2006:''' On November 24, 2006, the Title IX regulations were amended to provide greater flexibility in the operation of single-sex classes or extracurricular activities at the primary or secondary school level.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ed.gov/legislation/FedRegister/finrule/2006-4/102506a.html |title=Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance |journal=Federal Register |volume=71 |number=206 |date=October 25, 2006 |accessdate=2012-06-24}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox women |image = Chadgirl.jpg |caption = A Sara girl from Chad |gii = NR |gii_rank = NR |matdeath = 1,100 (2010) |womparl = 12.8% (2012) |femed = NA |womlab = 64.4% (2011) | ggg = 0.5588 (2013) | ggg_rank = 134th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12-13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} [[File:Mao Women.jpg|300px|right|[[Mao, Chad|Mao]] Women]] '''Women in Chad''', a landlocked country in [[Central Africa]], are the mainstay of its predominantly rural-based economy and they outnumber the men.<ref name="RPP-2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=fsi-grid2012|title=Rural Poverty in Chad|work=Rural poverty portal|publisher=International fund for agricultural development|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref>
Women face widespread discrimination and violence. Female genital mutilation, while technically illegal, is still widely practiced.<ref name="fh">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=22&year=2007&country=7153 Chad (2007)] Freedom House. Accessed on September 4, 2007.</ref> [[Extrajudicial killing]]s, beatings, torture, and rape were committed by [[Military of Chad|security forces]] and other abuses with "near total" impunity.<ref name="state">[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78726.htm "Chad"] Country Reports on Human Rights Practices 2006. United States Department of State. Accessed on September 4, 2007.</ref><ref name="hrw">[http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/chad14697.htm Chad: Events of 2006] Human Rights Watch. Accessed on September 4, 2007.</ref><ref name="ai">[http://www.amnestyusa.org/annualreport.php?id=ar&yr=2007&c=TCD Annual Report: Chad] Amnesty International. Accessed on September 4, 2007.</ref> [[Amnesty International]] has reported that "The widespread insecurity in eastern Chad had particularly severe consequences for women, who suffered grave [[human rights]] abuses, including rape, during attacks on villages" by [[Janjaweed|Janjawid militia]] from [[Sudan]].<ref name="ai"/>
== Education == {{Main|Education in Chad}} Despite the government's efforts, overall educational levels remained low at the end of the first decade of independence. In 1971 about 99 percent of women over the age of fifteen could not read, write, or speak French, which at the time was the only official national language; [[literacy]] in Arabic stood at 7.8 percent. In 1982 the overall literacy rate stood at about 15 percent.<ref name=cs>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/tdtoc.html Chad country study]. ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].</ref>
Major problems have hindered the development of Chadian education since independence. Financing for education has been very limited. Limited facilities and personnel also have made it difficult for the education system to provide adequate instruction. Overcrowding is a major problem; some classes have up 100 students, many of whom are repeaters. In the years just after independence, many primary-school teachers had only marginal qualifications. On the secondary level, the situation was even worse.<ref name=cs>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/tdtoc.html Chad country study]. ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].</ref>
In 2004, 39.6 percent of children ages 5 to 14 years were attending school. Educational opportunities for girls are limited, mainly due to cultural traditions. Fewer girls enroll in secondary school than boys, primarily due to early marriage. In 1999, 54.0 percent of children starting primary school reached grade 5.<ref name=ilab>"Chad". [http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/tda2005/tda2005.pdf ''2005 Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201190837/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/tda2005/tda2005.pdf |date=December 1, 2006 }}. [[Bureau of International Labor Affairs]], [[U.S. Department of Labor]] (2006). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].</ref>
== Women's rights == === Human trafficking === {{Main|Human trafficking in Chad}} Chad is a source and destination country for children subjected to trafficking in persons, specifically conditions of forced labor and forced [[prostitution]]. The country’s trafficking problem is primarily internal and frequently involves parents entrusting children to relatives or intermediaries in return for promises of education, apprenticeship, goods, or money; selling or bartering children into involuntary domestic servitude or herding is used as a means of survival by families seeking to reduce the number of mouths to feed.<ref name=dos>"Chad". [https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2010/142759.htm ''Trafficking in Persons Report 2010'']. [[U.S. Department of State]] (June 14, 2010). {{PD-notice}}</ref>
Underage Chadian girls travel to larger towns in search of work, where some are subsequently subjected to prostitution. Some girls are compelled to marry against their will, only to be forced by their husbands into involuntary domestic servitude or agricultural labor. In past reporting periods, traffickers transported children from Cameroon and the CAR to Chad’s oil producing regions for commercial sexual exploitation; it is unknown whether this practice persisted in 2009.<ref name=dos>"Chad". [https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2010/142759.htm ''Trafficking in Persons Report 2010'']. [[U.S. Department of State]] (June 14, 2010). {{PD-notice}}</ref>
===Female genital mutilation=== {{See|Prevalence of female genital mutilation by country}}
60 percent of Chadian women had been subject to [[female genital mutilation]] in 1995. The procedure is a traditional rite of passage as a girl moves into adulthood and it is followed regardless of religious orientation. It is equally common amongst Muslims, Christians and [[animist]]s. Those who attain adulthood without being mutilated generally avoid it for life.<ref name="USDoS-20010601">{{cite web|url=http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/chad/usdos01_fgm_Chad.pdf|title=Chad: Report on Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) or Female Genital Cutting (FGC)|date=1 June 2001|publisher=US Department of State|accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref> Over 80 percent of the girls in Chad who suffered genital mutilation had been cut between the age of 5 and 14.<ref name=UNICEF2013pp47,183>{{cite book|title=Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting: A statistical overview and exploration of the dynamics of change|url=http://data.unicef.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FGMC_Lo_res_Final_26.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|location=New York|date=2013|ref=harv}}, 47, 183.</ref>
===Gender Gap Report=== In 2012, the [[World Economic Forum]] ranked Chad among the worst regions in their [[Global Gender Gap Report]].<ref>[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2012%5C10%5C25%5Cstory_25-10-2012_pg7_23 Women still face gender gap in jobs, wages: report]</ref>
=== Polygamy === {{Main|Polygamy in Chad}} [[Polygamy]] is legal in Chad, and it is estimated that over a third of women live in polygamous [[marriages]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genderindex.org/country/chad|title=Chad|publisher=Social Institutions and Gender Index}}</ref>
== International treaties == Chad has signed and ratified the [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women]], the [[Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment]], the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] and the [[Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography]].<ref name='UN 8'> {{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-8&chapter=4&lang=en |title=United Nations Treaty Collection: Chapter IV: Human Rights: 8. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. New York, 18 December 1979 |accessdate=2012-08-29 |author=[[United Nations]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823144158/http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-8&chapter=4&lang=en |archivedate=23 August 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref name='UN 9'> {{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-9&chapter=4&lang=en |title=United Nations Treaty Collection: Chapter IV: Human Rights: 9. Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. New York, 10 December 1984 |accessdate=2012-08-29 |author=[[United Nations]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101108052518/https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-9&chapter=4&lang=en |archivedate=8 November 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name='UN 11'> {{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-11&chapter=4&lang=en |title=United Nations Treaty Collection: Chapter IV: Human Rights: 11. Convention on the Rights of the Child. New York, 20 November 1989 |accessdate=2012-08-29 |author=[[United Nations]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140211151110/http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-11&chapter=4&lang=en |archivedate=11 February 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref name='UN 11c'> {{cite web | url = http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-11-c&chapter=4&lang=en| title = United Nations Treaty Collection: Chapter IV: Human Rights: 11c. Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography. New York, 25 May 2000 | accessdate = 2012-08-29 | author = [[United Nations]]}}</ref>
